title: Owners Insurance Company v. Salmonsen
description: The Court determines the meaning of "occurrence" in a commercial general liability insurance policy in the context of a products liability case.
text:
owners ins. co. v. salmonsen


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
Owners Insurance Company, Plaintiff,
v.
Charles Salmonsen, individually and on behalf of all others similarly situated,
CDG, Inc. f/k/a Charleston Gypsum Dealers & Supply Co., Inc., Frank Crider, Raymond G.
Walford, Henry (Hank) Futch, and Harold Hal) Futch, Defendants.
      
    
  


ON CERTIFICATION FROM THE UNITED STATES
DISTRICT COURT, DISTRICT OF SOUTH CAROLINA

David C. Norton, United States District Court Judge 

Opinion No. 26059
Heard September 21, 2005 - Filed November 7, 2005

QUESTION ANSWERED


  
    
      
Morgan S. Templeton and Graham P. Powell, of Elmore & Wall, P.A., of Charleston, for plaintiff.
Mary Leigh Arnold, of Mt. Pleasant; and Steven L. Smith, of Smith, Collins & Newton, of Charleston, for defendants.
      
    
  


 JUSTICE MOORE:Â  We accepted this certified question to determine the meaning of the term â€œoccurrenceâ€ in a commercial general liability insurance policy.
FACTS
The underlying action in this federal case is a products liability class action arising from the sale of defective Parex, a synthetic stucco distributed by Defendant CGD, Inc.[1]Â  The defective stucco allegedly caused water intrusion that damaged class membersâ€™ property.Â  CGD was insured at the time under a commercial general liability insurance policy issued by Plaintiff Owners Insurance Company (Insurer).Â  Insurer sought a declaratory judgment that the policy in question does not provide coverage for this class action.
The district court ruled in favor of coverage but found an issue remains regarding the amount of coverage depending upon the meaning of the term â€œoccurrence.â€Â  The policy defines â€œoccurrenceâ€ as â€œan accident, including continuous or repeated exposure to substantially the same general harmful conditions.â€Â  If distribution of the stucco to various buyers is considered one occurrence, the policyâ€™s per occurrence limit of $1 million applies; if each sale is an occurrence, the aggregate limit of $2 million applies.Â  
The following question was certified to this Court:

To determine the number of occurrences for purposes of a commercial general liability insurance policyâ€™s liability limit, will South Carolina adopt the majority or minority rule?

ISSUE

Is each individual sale of a defective product an occurrence
or is the general act of distribution a single occurrence?

DISCUSSION
As discussed in various treatises, the majority rule in interpreting the meaning of â€œoccurrenceâ€ in a liability policy is the so-called â€œcause testâ€ which focuses on the cause of the damage rather than the number of claimants or injuries.Â  The minority view, on the other hand, focuses on the effect of the insuredâ€™s action and considers each event or each injury a separate occurrence.Â  See generally Michael Sullivan, Annotation, What Constitutes Single Accident or Occurrence within Liability Policy Limiting Insurerâ€™s Liability to a Specified Amount Per Accident or Occurrence, 64 A.L.R.4th 668 (2004); Am.L. Prod. Liab. 3d Â§ 58:28 (2005); 46 C.J.S. Insurance Â§ 1129 (2005).Â  The discussion of a majority-versus-minority view summarizes an amalgam of cases, including vehicle accidents, flooding, fist-fights, and so on,[2] and is not limited to product liability cases.Â  Notably, there is no prevailing view in the specific context of product liability cases involving the distribution of a defective product.Â  Compare Champion Internatâ€™l Corp. v. Continental Cas. Co., 546 F.2d 502 (2d Cir. 1976) (repeated sale of defective paneling was only one occurrence), and Murice Pincoffs Co. v. St. Paul Fire & Marine Ins. Co., 447 F.2d 204 (5th Cir. 1971) (each sale of defective bird feed was separate occurrence). Â In light of the diverse contexts in which the meaning of â€œoccurrenceâ€ may arise, we decline the district courtâ€™s invitation to simply choose the majority or minority view and instead focus narrowly on the issue at hand. 
This case involves the distribution of inherently defective goods, and not the defective distribution of otherwise satisfactory goods.[3]Â  There is no indication CGD defectively distributed the product in question.Â  Further, the policy here provides coverage for an â€œoccurrenceâ€ including a â€œcontinuous and repeated exposure to substantially the same general harmful conditions.â€ Â Because the distributor has taken no distinct action giving rise to liability for each sale, we conclude under this policy definition that placing a defective product into the stream of commerce is one occurrence. 
Accordingly, we limit our ruling on this issue by focusing on the specific context and policy language before us and conclude there has been a single occurrence.
QUESTION ANSWERED.
 TOAL, C.J., WALLER, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

[1]The seller of defective goods may be liable under S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-73-10 (2005). 
[2]See Annot., supra, Â§Â§ 8-19. 
[3]We are persuaded by Insurerâ€™s argument that Michigan Chem. Corp. v. American Home Assurance Co., 728 F.2d 374 (6th Cir. 1984), a products liability case, is distinguishable from the case before us.Â  In that case, the federal court, applying Illinois law, concluded that each shipment was a separate occurrence where the insured accidentally shipped flame retardant instead of a feed supplement.Â  The flame retardant was mixed into livestock feed sold to farmers whose animals had to be destroyed as a result of the contamination.Â  It was the insuredâ€™s defective distribution which caused the damage rather than an inherent defect in the product as manufactured.

The Supreme Court of South Carolina



The Supreme Court of South Carolina
In the Matter of Arthur T. 
  Meeder, Petitioner.

ORDER

 In 1997, petitioner was disbarred. In the Matter of Meeder, 327 S.C. 169, 488 S.E.2d 875 (1997). Petitioner has now filed a petition for reinstatement. The Committee on Character and Fitness recommends the petition be granted upon certain conditions.
  We grant the petition for reinstatement, subject to the following conditions:

  1. For a minimum of two years after his reinstatement, petitioner shall limit his practice to construction law.
    
    2. For a minimum of two years after his reinstatement, petitioner shall be employed as an attorney with George Mullen, Esquire. 
    During the first two years of petitioner’s reinstatement and employment with Mr. Mullen, Mr. Mullen shall file quarterly reports with the Office of Disciplinary Counsel which detail petitioner’s progress in returning to the practice of law. 
	 
  3. Petitioner shall maintain a patient-physician relationship with Dr. Ziad Nahas or someone of similar skill and expertise. For the two year period following petitioner’s reinstatement, the physician shall provide ODC with quarterly reports addressing petitioner’s progress. Thereafter, the physician shall file semiannual reports with ODC which address petitioner’s progress. 
      
      4. Within two (2) years from the date of his reinstatement, petitioner shall make restitution of $36,000 to Mr. and Mrs. Harold Coar. When he has completed payment of restitution, petitioner shall provide ODC with proof that he has made full restitution to the Coars. 
      
      5. Petitioner shall obtain the “Revised Lawyers Oath” continuing legal education video/DVD and related form affidavit from the South Carolina Bar. After viewing the video/DVD, petitioner shall complete the affidavit and return the video/DVD and completed affidavit to the South Carolina Bar. The South Carolina Bar shall notify the Clerk in writing that petitioner has completed this condition. 
	 

 Once the South Carolina Bar notifies the Clerk that petitioner has signed the affidavit attesting to viewing the “Revised Lawyers Oath” video/DVD, petitioner shall be scheduled to be sworn in. 
 
 IT IS SO ORDERED.

title: Brown v. Berkeley County
description: The Court affirmed the lower courtâ€™s decision and held that the Berkeley County Councilâ€™s resolution authorizing a special audit of the Clerk of Courtâ€™s Office articulated the â€œfunctional equivalentâ€ of necessity.  The Court also held that the denial of a motion to dismiss brought by individual members of the Berkeley County Council was interlocutory and not immediately appealable.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
Mary P. Brown, individually and in her capacity as Berkeley County Clerk of Court, Appellant/Respondent,
v.
The County of Berkeley, James H. Rozier, Jr., in his official capacity as Berkeley County Supervisor and Chairman of Berkeley County Council and individually; William E. Crosby, in his official capacity as Vice Chairman of Berkeley County Council and individually; Charles E. Davis, Steve C. Davis, Milton Farley, Dennis L. Fish, Judy C. Mims, Caldwell
Pinkney, Jr., and Judith K. Spooner, each in their official capacity as Berkeley County Council members and individually,
Defendants,
Of Whom The County of Berkeley, James H. Rozier, Jr., in his official capacity as Berkeley County Supervisor and Chairman of Berkeley County Council and individually; William E Crosby, in his official capacity as Vice Chairman of Berkeley County Council and individually; Charles E. Davis, Steve C. Davis, Milton Farley, Dennis L. Fish, Caldwell
Pinkney, Jr., and Judith K. Spooner, each in their official capacity as Berkeley County Council members and individually are
 Respondents/Appellants,
and
Judy C. Mims is Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal from Berkeley County
Â Thomas L. Hughston, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 26062
Heard October 4, 2005 - Filed November 14, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Margaret D. Fabri, of Charleston, for Appellant/Respondent.
D. Mark Stokes, of Moncks Corner, for Respondent/Appellant Berkeley County.
Sandra J. Senn and Stephanie P. McDonald, both of Charleston, for all other Respondents/Appellants.
James A. Stuckey, Jr., of Charleston, for Respondent Judy C. Mims.
      
    
  


 CHIEF JUSTICE TOAL:Â  This is an appeal from the trial courtâ€™s refusal to grant a preliminary injunction preventing a â€œspecial auditâ€ of the Berkeley County Clerk of Courtâ€™s Office.Â  The individual members of the Berkeley County Council cross-appeal the denial of their motion to dismiss Mary P. Brownâ€™s claims for defamation, defamation per se, and intentional infliction of emotional distress.Â  This case was certified for review pursuant to Rule 204(b), SCACR.Â  We affirm.
Factual/Procedural Background
This is a dispute between branches of Berkeley County Government.Â  Mary P. Brown (Brown) has served as the Berkeley County Clerk of Court (the Clerk) since being first elected to that office in 1983.Â  Under South Carolina law, Berkeley County (the County) is subject to an annual financial audit conducted by independent and outside auditors.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 4-9-150 (Supp. 2004).Â  The outside financial audit for the fiscal year 2002-2003 began in early August, 2003.Â  
In November of 2003, the outside auditor issued a financial report to the County.Â  The auditor found no major instances of noncompliance, but did report some â€œimmaterial instances of noncompliance.â€Â  Over the course of the next few months, the auditor raised concerns regarding Brownâ€™s use of the county credit card, the reporting of interest earned on the Clerkâ€™s escrow accounts, and instances of payments to employees that may not have been reported on the proper federal tax forms.Â  The auditor also observed that certain details of the Clerkâ€™s handling of discretionary funds, specifically funds collected by the issuance of professional or surety bondsman licenses, were not maintained in accordance with the applicable statutes.Â  Throughout this process of investigation, the auditor maintained that these findings did not materially alter the November report.Â  The auditor instead classified these findings as â€œopportunities for strengthening internal controls and operating efficiency.â€Â  
The dispute in this case involves the actions of the Berkeley County Council (the County Council) during this same time period.Â  In November of 2003, the County Council enacted a written request for Brown to produce financial documentation for the past two years regarding ten (10) county bank and credit card accounts.Â  In reply to the County Councilâ€™s request, Brown asserted that the County Council violated the Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) by authorizing the request to produce in a closed executive session.Â  Brown additionally claimed that James H. Rozier, Jr., Supervisor and Chairman of the County Council, improperly accused Brown of misusing the county credit card.Â  Following three months of discourse between the clerkâ€™s office and the County Council, the County Council enacted a resolution approving an â€œexpanded audit[1]â€ of the clerkâ€™s office.Â  Brown filed suit seeking, among other forms of relief, a preliminary injunction prohibiting the audit of the clerkâ€™s office, and damages against the County, the County Council, and the individual council members for defamation, defamation per se, and intentional infliction of emotional distress.
The trial court denied Brownâ€™s motion for a preliminary injunction, relying largely on the language of S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 4-9-150.[2] Â Â The trial court found that the County Council was not free to interfere with the operation of the clerkâ€™s office in a manner that was unreasonable, unduly burdensome, or of a harassing nature, but the trial court found no evidence of such action in this case.
In the same order, the trial court declined to dismiss the individual council members â€œat this early stage.â€Â  The individual council members had moved for dismissal from the lawsuit citing the terms of the South Carolina Tort Claims Act and absolute legislative immunity.
Both parties appealed, and the following issues have been raised for review:

  
    
      
        I. 
         Did the trial court err in denying Brownâ€™s request for a preliminary injunction to prevent the expanded audit?Â 
      
      
        
         
      
      
        II. 
         Did the trial court err in denying the individual council membersâ€™ motion to dismiss?
      
    
  

Law/Analysis
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Brownâ€™s Request for a Preliminary Injunction.
Brown argues that the trial court erred in denying her request for a preliminary injunction.Â  We disagree.Â  
Generally, actions for injunctive relief are equitable in nature.Â  Wiedemann v. Town of Hilton Head, 344 S.C. 233, 236, 542 S.E.2d 752, 753 (Ct. App. 2001). Â In equitable actions, the appellate court may review the record and make findings of fact in accordance with its own view of the evidence.Â  Doe v. Clark, 318 S.C. 274, 276, 457 S.E.2d 336, 337 (1995).Â  To obtain an injunction, a party must demonstrate a likelihood of success on the merits, irreparable harm, and the absence of an adequate remedy at law.Â  County of Richland v. Simpkins, 348 S.C. 664, 669, 560 S.E.2d 902, 904 (Ct. App. 2002).  
Brown claims that the special audit ordered by the County Council is invalid because the County Council did not articulate specific reasons why such an audit was necessary.Â  The relevant portion of the code provides in part:

The council shall provide for an independent annual audit of all financial records and transactions of the county and any agency funded in whole by county funds and may provide for more frequent audits as it considers necessary.Â  Special audits may be provided for any agency receiving county funds as the county governing body considers necessary.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 4-9-150 (Supp. 2004) (emphasis added).Â  
Clear and unambiguous words in a statute should be given their plain and ordinary meaning.Â  In re Vincent J., 333 S.C. 233, 235, 509 S.E.2d 261, 262 (1998) (citing Gilstrap v. S.C. Budget and Control Bd., 310 S.C. 210, 423 S.E.2d 101 (1992)).Â  In this case, the plain language of the statute unequivocally allows a county government to order special audits whenever the county government considers the audit necessary.Â  
The instant case does not require this Court to look beyond the plain words of the statute and interpret the meaning of the phrase â€œconsiders necessary.â€Â  The resolution adopted by the County Council clearly outlines (1) that the County Council has previously made requests for the Clerk to provide financial information, including documentation in support of certain financial transactions, (2) that the Clerk has refused to provide the requested documentation, (3) that the funds involved are public funds, and (4) that the County Council feels that the most appropriate method of ensuring the proper use of public funds is to request a special audit of the clerkâ€™s office. Â This constitutes the functional equivalent of articulating necessity, and no reasonable construction of the statute at issue could require the County Council to do more in the way of offering justification for a special audit.Â  Were we to adopt the position advocated by Brown, our conclusion would inevitably be the same.[3]Â  For this reason, we affirm the trial courtâ€™s decision denying Brownâ€™s request for a preliminary injunction.[4]
II.Â Â Â Â Â  The Motion to Dismiss the Individual Defendants.
The individual council members argue that they should be dismissed from Brownâ€™s suit pursuant to the principle of absolute immunity and the terms of the South Carolina Tort Claims Act.Â  We disagree and instead hold that the denial of the individual council membersâ€™ motion to dismiss is not reviewable at this time.
It is well settled that an interlocutory order is not immediately appealable unless it involves the merits of the case or affects a substantial right.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 14-3-330 (Supp. 2003); Woodward v. Westvaco Corp., 319 S.C. 240, 243, 460 S.E.2d 392, 394 (1995); Mid-State Distributors, Inc. v. Century Importers, 310 S.C. 330, 334-35, 426 S.E.2d 777, 780 (1993); Shields v. Martin Marietta Corp., 303 S.C. 469, 470, 402 S.E.2d 482, 483 (1991).Â  To involve the merits of a case, the order must â€œfinally determine some substantial matter forming the whole or a part of some cause of action or defense.â€Â  Woodward, 319 S.C. at 243, 460 S.E.2d at 394.Â  To affect a substantial right, the order must â€œdetermine the action and prevent a judgment from which an appeal might be taken or discontinue the action.â€ Â Id.Â  We decide, then, whether the trial courtâ€™s order denying the individual council membersâ€™ motion to dismiss is an immediately appealable order.
Individual members of a local county council are not entitled to absolute immunity. Â See Richardson v. McGill, 273 S.C. 142, 146, 255 S.E.2d 341, 343 (1979) (noting that privilege depends not on rigid requirements but is determined by consideration of public policy).Â  Furthermore, the trial courtâ€™s denial of the individual council membersâ€™ motion to dismiss does not preclude the individual council members from raising the issues presented in their motion at a later point in the case.Â  See Frazier v. Badger, 361 S.C. 94, 101, 603 S.E.2d 587, 590 (2004) (stating that immunity under the Tort Claims Act is an affirmative defense that must be proved at trial); Sanders v. Prince, 304 S.C. 236, 240, 403 S.E.2d 640, 643 (1991) (stating that when a government employeeâ€™s conduct constitutes actual malice, he is not entitled to immunity from suit).Â  
The South Carolina Tort Claims Act provides â€œ[n]othing in this chapter may be construed to give an employee of a governmental entity immunity from suitâ€¦if it is proved that the employeeâ€™s conduct was not within the scope of his official duties or that it constituted actual fraud, actual malice, intent to harm, or a crime involving moral turpitude.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-78-70 (b) (2005).Â  Were we to recognize that the individual members of the county council enjoyed absolute immunity from suit, the above statute would be meaningless.Â  Additionally, the individual council members will be free to raise such issues as qualified immunity, qualified privilege, and the provisions of the Tort Claims Act, at later stages of this case. Â For these reasons, we hold that the denial of the individual council membersâ€™ motion to dismiss is not presently reviewable.[5]
Conclusion
We affirm the trial courtâ€™s refusal to issue a preliminary injunction preventing a special audit of the Berkeley County Clerk of Courtâ€™s Office. Because the grounds laid out in the County Councilâ€™s resolution authorizing the special audit constitute the functional equivalent of articulating necessity, we need not answer the question of whether a county government must articulate necessity in authorizing a special audit under S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 4-9-150 (Supp. 2004).Â  
Because the denial of the individual members of the Berkeley County Councilâ€™s motion to dismiss is an interlocutory order and neither involves the merits nor affects a substantial right of the parties, we hold that this motion is not presently subject to appellate review.
 MOORE, WALLER, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

[1] The terms â€œspecial auditâ€ and â€œexpanded auditâ€ are used interchangeably.Â  The County Councilâ€™s resolution calls for an â€œexpanded audit,â€ and the statute at issue, S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 4-9-150 (Supp. 2004), uses the term â€œspecial audit.â€Â  Both terms refer to the same activity.
[2] S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 4-9-150 (Supp. 2004) states that special audits may be provided for any agency receiving county funds as the governing body considers necessary.
[3] Brown asks this Court to interpret Â§ 4-9-150 to require the County Council to articulate why a special audit is necessary.
[4] Brown also argues that through the special audit, the County Council is exerting improper control over the constitutionally created office of the Clerk of Court and that the Clerkâ€™s Office would be irreparably harmed by the auditorâ€™s â€œopen ended and burdensomeâ€ demand for documents and information.Â  We decline to address the issue of harm as the trial courtâ€™s ruling on the temporary injunction is affirmed for reasons already stated. 
[5] Courts have made a practice of accepting appeals of denials of interlocutory orders not ordinarily immediately appealable when these appeals are companion to issues that are reviewable. Pitts v. Jackson Natâ€™l Life Ins. Co., 352 S.C. 319, 338, 574 S.E.2d 502, 512 (Ct. App. 2002) (citing Morris v. Anderson County, 349 S.C. 607, 610, 564 S.E.2d 649, 651 (2002)).Â  In the instant case, however, the two issues argued on appeal (the denial of a preliminary injunction preventing a special audit and the denial of a motion to dismiss claims for defamation, defamation per se, and intentional infliction of emotional distress) lack a sufficient nexus or companionship to justify this Courtâ€™s exercise of immediate appellate review.

title: Smith v. Doe
description: The Court held that an action for paternity and child support on behalf of a disabled adult was not barred by the statute of limitations.
text:
In this action to establish paternity and award child support, the family court declared that John Doe (Doe) was the father and ordered Doe to pay child support


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
 Jane Smith, Respondent,
v.
John Doe, Petitioner.
      
    
  


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI TO THE COURT OF APPEALS

Appeal from Lexington County
Â C. David Sawyer, Jr., Family Court Judge

Opinion No. 26063
Heard October 5, 2005 - Filed November 14, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
H. Wayne Floyd, of W. Columbia, for Petitioner.
John D. Elliott, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  


CHIEF JUSTICE TOAL:Â  Jane Smith (Smith) brought this action to establish paternity and award child support.Â  The family court declared that John Doe (Doe) was the father and ordered Doe to pay child support.Â  The court of appeals held that Doe had an ongoing duty to support the child (Danielle) and that the action was not barred by the statute of limitations.Â  On appeal, the court of appeals held that the amount of the child support award was reasonable.Â  We affirm the court of appeals.
Factual / Procedural Background
The child in the present case, Danielle, was thirty-four years old when this action was commenced.Â  Danielle is the child of Doe and Smith.Â  Smith and Doe met in 1964, and although Doe was married at the time, the two had an affair.Â  Danielle, the result of the affair, was born in July of 1965.
Danielle is mentally handicapped and has the mental capacity of a six-year-old.Â  Danielle does not have the capacity to read, do math, cook, or drive.Â  In addition, Danielle cannot be left unsupervised, and as a result, she is under childcare supervision most of the day.Â  
Doe was aware Danielleâ€™s birth but did not have a relationship with her or offer support to her.Â  Out of concern for Danielleâ€™s well being, Smith asked Doe if he would recognize Danielle as his daughter in order to allow Danielle to receive Social Security benefits upon Doeâ€™s death.Â  Doe refused to recognize Danielle as his child.Â  As a result, Smith filed an action against Doe seeking a declaration of child support and paternity.Â  
Doe filed a motion to dismiss, denying that he was Danielleâ€™s father and arguing that the action was barred by the statute of limitations.Â  The family court denied the motion and ordered the parties to undergo paternity testing.Â  The paternity test revealed that Doe was Danielleâ€™s father.
As a result, the court ordered Doe to pay $91.00 per week in child support starting from the commencement of the action and the court also ordered Doe to pay attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  The court of appeals affirmed the decision of the family court, rejecting Doeâ€™s argument that the statute of limitations barred the action.Â  Doe appealed and this Court granted certiorari to review the following issues:

  
    
      
        I. 
         Does the general statute of limitations bar Smithâ€™s paternity and child support actions?
      
      
        
         
      
      
        II.  
         Did the family court err in awarding child support?
      
    
  

Law / Analysis
I.                 
Statute of Limitations 
Doe argues that the court of appeals erred in holding that the statute of limitations did not bar the paternity and child support actions.Â  We disagree.Â  The action to determine paternity and the action for child support are separate actions, however, in the present case the actions were brought together.Â  We will address the support obligation first.
A.              
Support Obligation 
When a child is so physically or mentally disabled that the child cannot support himself or herself, the parentâ€™s duty to support the child continues beyond the child reaching the age of majority.Â  Riggs v. Riggs, 353 S.C. 230, 234-35, 578 S.E.2d 3, 5 (2003).Â  When the disability prevents the child from becoming emancipated, the presumption of emancipation upon reaching the age of majority is inapplicable.Â  Parker v. Parker, 230 S.C. 28, 31, 94 S.E.2d 12, 13 (1956).
In Riggs v. Riggs, this Court held that a parentâ€™s support obligation continued past the age of majority even when the disability was not diagnosed until after the child reached age eighteen.Â  353 S.C. at 235, 578 S.E.2d at 5 (2003).Â  The child in Riggs was diagnosed with Leighâ€™s Syndrome after reaching eighteen.Â  As a result of the degenerative condition, the child was not able to function above the level of a ten-year-old and had mobility problems.Â  The Court held that even though the child had reached the age of majority, the disability prevented the child from being emancipated.Â  Id. Â Â Â Â Â  
In the present case, Danielle is thirty-four years old, but unlike the child in Riggs, Danielleâ€™s condition manifested at birth.Â  However, due to her disability, Danielle is incapable of being emancipated.Â  As a result, we hold that Doeâ€™s support obligation did not terminate when Danielle reached the age of majority.Â  Accordingly, we affirm the court of appealsâ€™ decision holding that the action for support was not barred by the statute of limitations.
B.              
Paternity 
Doe argues that the paternity action is barred by the general statute of limitations.[1]Â  We disagree.Â  This Court has not directly addressed the issue of whether an action to determine paternity can be barred by the statute of limitations.Â  
As noted by the court of appeals, some jurisdictions have placed a statute of limitations on bringing an action for paternity.Â  See e.g., 23 PA. Cons. Stat. Ann. Â§ 4343(b) (2003) (requiring that a paternity action be instituted within eighteen years of the childâ€™s birth).
The South Carolina legislature has passed statutes addressing both a parentâ€™s support obligation and a procedure outlining paternity testing.[2]Â  Nowhere in this stateâ€™s statutory law is a there a time limit for when an action for paternity may be commenced.[3]Â  
The statutory authority read in conjunction with this Courtâ€™s common law makes it clear that the legislature did not intend to impose a statute of limitations on paternity actions because the Legislature did not specifically include one in the statutory scheme.Â  See Gilstrap v. S.C. Budget & Control Bd., 310 S.C. 210, 214, 423 S.E.2d 101, 103 (1992) (holding that the Court will give statutory provisions reasonable and practical construction consistent with the purpose and policy of the entire act). 
As a result, we affirm the court of appeals, but hold that there is no statute of limitations that is applicable for an action to determine paternity.
II.              
Amount of Child Support 
Doe argues that the court of appeals erred in determining the amount of child support.Â  We disagree.
Child support awards are within the sound discretion of the trial judge and will not be disturbed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion.Â  Mitchell v. Mitchell, 283 S.C. 87, 92, 320 S.E.2d 706, 710 (1984).Â  The trial court abuses its discretion when factual findings are without evidentiary support or a ruling is based upon an error of law.Â  McKnight v. McKnight, 283 S.C. 540, 543, 324 S.E.2d 91, 93 (Ct. App. 1984).
In the present case, the family court accounted for all income received by Danielle.Â  The court recognized that Danielle received social security benefits of $275 per month.Â  In addition, the court noted that Danielle receives between $250 and $350 per
month from her job at the Babcock Center.Â  The family court used the child support guidelines and ordered Doe to pay $91.00 per week in support.Â  The court refused to deviate from the guidelines.
We hold that the family court did not err in determining the amount of support to which Danielle was entitled.Â  The court followed the child support guidelines and accounted for all income Danielle was receiving in order to reach the total amount of support Doe is obligated to pay.
As a result, we affirm the court of appealsâ€™ decision finding that the family court did not err in awarding child support.
Conclusion
Based on the above reasoning, we affirm the court of appeals.
 MOORE, WALLER, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

[1]  The general Statute of limitations is codified at
S.C. Code Ann. Section 15-3-530 (Supp. 2004).
[2] See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-952 (Supp. 2003) (allowing paternity actions by and on behalf of children older than eighteen); S.C. Code Ann Â§ 20-7-90 (Supp. 2004) (requiring parents to provide support for their legitimate and illegitimate children).
[3] Upon review of this Courtâ€™s jurisprudence, it seems that statute of limitations issues have arisen only in limited situations involving a parentâ€™s duty of support.Â Â  S.C. Depâ€™t of Soc. Serv. v. Lowman, 269 S.C. 41, 236 S.E.2d 194 (1977).Â  In Lowman, this Court held that the general statute of limitations applied to a support obligation but only in an action to seek retroactive child support.Â  Id. at 47, 236 S.E.2d at 196.Â  Further, the Court stated that although a claim for retroactive support might be barred, â€œthe duty of support is a continuing obligation.Â  New causes of action arise over the years with each instance of a putative fatherâ€™s failure to support his child.â€Â  Id. at 48, 236 S.E.2d at 196.Â  (citation omitted).

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA

Henry B. Richardson, Jr., Disciplinary Counsel, and Assistant Deputy Attorney General J. Emory Smith, Jr., both of Columbia, for the Office of Disciplinary Counsel.

PER CURIAM:Â Â  In this attorney disciplinary matter, respondent and the Office of Disciplinary Counsel (ODC) have entered into an Agreement for Discipline by Consent (Agreement) pursuant to Rule 21, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR.Â  In the Agreement, respondent admits misconduct and consents to a public reprimand or a definite suspension not to exceed thirty (30) days.Â  See Rule 7(b), RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR.Â  We accept the Agreement and definitely suspend respondent from the practice of law in this state for a thirty (30) day period.Â  The facts, as set forth in the Agreement, are as follows.Â  
FACTS
Matter I
Respondent admits he was not as diligent as he should have been in handling a domestic case.Â  He failed to adequately communicate with his client. 
Matter II
Respondent admits he was not diligent in notifying his client of the hearing dates.Â  In addition, he did not meet with his client to prepare her for a hearing.Â  He admits he failed to respond in a timely manner to ODCâ€™s request for additional information.Â  
Matter III
Respondent failed to perfect service of a summons and complaint and later failed to file an amended complaint in a timely manner.Â  Both actions were dismissed.Â  Respondent failed to respond to ODCâ€™s initial inquiry and did not respond in a timely manner to ODCâ€™s second letter of inquiry.Â  Respondent agrees to repay this clientâ€™s attorneyâ€™s fees in the amount of $750.00 within one year of the date he signed the Agreement.[1]
Matter IV
Respondent failed to diligently pursue his clientâ€™s domestic action.Â  He failed to adequately communicate with his client.
Matter V
Respondent failed to respond to a motion for summary judgment and failed to appear at the summary judgment hearing.Â  Summary judgment was granted to the opposing party.Â  
Respondent maintains he had expected his client to either obtain other counsel or contact him if she wanted him to respond to the summary judgment motion, however, he failed to obtain his clientâ€™s written consent or the approval of the court to withdraw from representation.Â  In addition, on an earlier occasion, respondent failed to communicate with the client.
Matter VI
Respondent failed to diligently defend a civil forfeiture action against his client.Â  As a result, the answer was late and a default judgment was entered.Â  Respondent failed to adequately communicate with his client and failed to return the $3,000.00 retainer fee he did not earn.Â  Respondent also delayed in responding to inquiries from
ODC.
Respondent agrees to repay the $3,000.00 fee to his client within one year of the date he signed the Agreement.Â  
Matter VII
Respondent signed his clientâ€™s name to a bond assignment form without authorization.Â  The form provided that $7,500.00 of the posted bond money was to be assigned to respondentâ€™s firm for its fee.Â  Although he did not have the authority to sign the form, the amount of the fee was not in dispute.Â  Respondent was not prosecuted. 
Matter VIII
Respondent failed to diligently handle a case and to adequately communicate with his client.Â  Respondent failed to safely maintain the clientâ€™s file and the file was lost.Â  Respondent agrees to return the clientâ€™s retainer fee of $1,200.00 within one year of signing the Agreement.
Matter IX
In this matter, respondent failed to serve and file a notice of appeal from a clientâ€™s conviction.Â  He failed to continue to represent the client until relieved by the court.Â  
Respondent further admits he unsuccessfully tried to establish personal relationships with a female client and with a woman who hired him to represent a third person.Â  Respondent now recognizes such relationships are to be avoided because they often lead to a conflict of interest.Â  
LAW
Respondent admits that by his misconduct he has violated the following provisions of the Rules of Professional Conduct, Rule 407, SCACR: Rule 1.3 (lawyer shall act with reasonable diligence and promptness in representing a client); Rule 1.4 (a) (lawyer shall keep a client reasonably informed concerning the status of a matter and promptly comply with reasonable requests for information); Rule 1.7 (lawyer shall not represent a client if the representation of that client will be materially limited by the lawyerâ€™s own interests); Rule 1.15 (lawyer shall promptly deliver funds and property to a client; lawyer shall promptly deliver an accounting about client property); Rule 1.16 (upon termination of representation, lawyer shall take steps to extent reasonably practicable to protect the clientâ€™s interests);
Rule 8.4(a) (lawyer shall not violate Rules of Professional Conduct); Rule 8.4(d) (lawyer shall not engage in conduct involving dishonesty, fraud, deceit, or misrepresentation); and Rule 8.4(e) (lawyer shall not engage in conduct that is prejudicial to administration of justice).[2]
Â Respondent further admits his misconduct constitutes a violation of Rule 7, RLDE, of Rule 413, SCACR, specifically Rule 7(a)(1) (lawyer shall not violate Rules of Professional Conduct or any other rules of this jurisdiction regarding professional conduct of lawyers) and Rule 7(a)(5) (lawyer shall not engage in conduct tending to pollute the administration of justice or to bring the courts or the legal profession into disrepute or conduct demonstrating an unfitness to practice law).Â Â  
CONCLUSION
We accept the Agreement and definitely suspend respondent from the practice of law for a thirty (30) day period.Â  Furthermore, as part of the Courtâ€™s sanction, we adopt respondentâ€™s agreement to repay his clients in the amounts stated herein within one year from the date respondent signed the Agreement.Â  See Footnote 1. Within fifteen days of the date of this opinion, respondent shall file an affidavit with the Clerk of Court showing that he has complied with Rule 30, RLDE, Rule 413,
SCACR.
 DEFINITE SUSPENSION.
 TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

[1] Respondent signed the Agreement on June 30, 2005.Â  
[2]Â  Respondentâ€™s misconduct occurred before the effective date of the Amendments to the Rules of Professional Conduct.Â  See Court Order dated June 20, 2005.Â  The Rules cited in this opinion are those which were in effect at the time of respondentâ€™s misconduct.Â

IN THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA


IN THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
In the Matter of Lillie R. Davis, Respondent.
      
    
  


Opinion No. 26065
Submitted September 27, 2005 - Filed November 14, 2005

DEFINITE SUSPENSION


  
    
      
Henry B. Richardson, Jr., Disciplinary Counsel, and Robert E. Bogan, Assistant Deputy Attorney General, both of Columbia, for the Office of Disciplinary Counsel. 
Susan B. Lipscomb, of Parker Poe Adams & Bernstein, LLP, ofÂ  Columbia, for respondent.Â  
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â Â  In this attorney disciplinary matter, respondent and the Office of Disciplinary Counsel (ODC) have entered into an Agreement for Discipline by Consent (Agreement) pursuant to Rule 21, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR.Â  In the Agreement, respondent admits misconduct and consents to the imposition of a definite suspension not to exceed two years or any lesser sanction set forth in Rule 7(b), RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR.Â  We accept the Agreement and impose a two year definite suspension from the practice of law.Â  The facts, as set forth in the Agreement, are as follows:Â  
FACTS 
On January 28, 2002, respondent was suspended from the practice of law for twenty (20) months.Â  In the Matter of Davis, 348 S.C. 199, 599 S.E.2d 573 (2002).[1]Â  At the time of her suspension, respondent assured ODC that she would close her practice in an orderly manner and that it was not necessary to appoint an attorney to protect her clientsâ€™ interests.Â  
In connection with her suspension and the closing of her practice, respondent executed an affidavit on February 12, 2002, in which she attested to her compliance with Rule 30, RLDE.Â  In relevant part, respondentâ€™s affidavit states:

  
    
      
        
        
      
      
        4.  
        In accordance with Rule 30 of Rule 413, SCAR [sic] I have notified by registered or certified mail, return receipt requested, all clients
          being represented by me in a pending matter.Â  
      
      
        
         
      
      
        5. 
         The notice advises the client of the suspension and of the consequent inability to act as an attorney.Â  The notice also advises the client to seek legal advice of the clientâ€™s own
          choice elsewhere, and, if the matter involves pending litigation or administrative proceedings, of the desirability of the prompt substitution of another lawyer to act as the clientâ€™s attorney in the proceeding.
      
      
        
         
      
      
        6. 
        I have also notified or caused to be notified, any co-counsel in any pending matter and any opposing counsel, or in the absence of opposing counsel, the adverse parties, of the suspension and the consequent inability of the lawyer to act as an attorney.Â  The notice states my place of residence.Â 
      
      
        
         
      
      
        7. 
        In the event the client did not obtain substitute counsel within ten days of the notice, I moved in the court or agency in which the proceedings were pending for leave to withdraw.
      
      
        
         
      
      
        8.   
        I have promptly refunded any fees paid in advance that have not been earned.Â  I have delivered to all clients being represented in pending matters any papers of [sic] other property to which they are entitled and notified them of and any counsel representing them of a suitable time and place where the papers and other property may be obtained, calling attention to any urgency for obtaining the papers and other property.
      
      
        
         
      
      
        9. 
         I have kept and will maintain records showing compliance with the requirements of Rule 30 of Rule 413, SCAR [sic] and shall make these records available to disciplinary counsel upon request.Â 
      
    
  

Underline added.Â  
Matter I
On or about January 23, 2002, Client A met with and retained respondent for a domestic matter.Â  At that meeting, Client A executed a fee agreement for $2,500 and paid respondent $200 towards that fee.Â  Client A paid the balance of the fee, $2,300, a few days later.Â  
After learning respondentâ€™s telephone had beenÂ  disconnected, Client A alleges she telephoned the Commission on Lawyer Conduct and discovered respondent had been suspended.Â  Although Client A acknowledges she learned of respondentâ€™s suspension before respondent executed the above-referenced affidavit of compliance with Rule 30, Client A alleges she did not subsequently receive written notice as respondent represented in the affidavit.Â  Respondent does not dispute Client Aâ€™s allegation for purposes of the Agreement, but explains she believes Client was sent notice in compliance with Rule 30.Â  
Respondent did not refund the unearned portion of Client Aâ€™s fee as represented in her affidavit.Â  Client A petitioned the Lawyersâ€™ Fund for Client Protection (Lawyersâ€™ Fund) which determined Client A was entitled to $2,500. 
Matter II
At the time of her suspension on January 28, 2002, respondent was shown on the records of the United States Bankruptcy Court as counsel of record in twelve pending bankruptcy matters, though respondent represents two of the matters had been concluded. Â As of February 27, 2002, fifteen days after executing the above-referenced affidavit, respondent remained counsel of record in nine bankruptcy matters according to the records of the Bankruptcy Court.Â  Orders of substitution in two of those matters were not submitted to the Bankruptcy Court until May 2002.Â  
Respondent explains that she may have continued to appear as counsel on the bankruptcy courtâ€™s records because some of the matters had been dismissed, but orders had not yet been issued, and because other matters were inactive and clients were making payments. 
Matter III
In February 2001, Client B paid respondent $1,200 in fees for a divorce matter.Â  Client B alleges that she made several long distance telephone calls and trips to Columbia from Orangeburg to attempt to contact respondent, but usually reached respondentâ€™s Â answering machine or was told that respondent was not â€œinâ€ but would be â€œin touch.â€Â  Respondent represents that she met with Client B whenever Client B had a scheduled appointment, but has no knowledge of Client Bâ€™s trips to Columbia or long distance telephone calls.Â  
In addition, Client Bâ€™s complaint to ODC, dated March 25, 2002, alleged that respondent had not notified her that she had been suspended from the practice of law.Â  
Respondent provided ODC with a copy of an unsigned letter dated May 2, 2002, from respondent to Client B, in which respondent notified Client B of the suspension, purported to return Client Bâ€™s file, and offered to substitute respondentâ€™s brother or â€œa couple of my colleaguesâ€ as counsel or, alternatively, return $550 in unearned fees.
Respondentâ€™s response to the Notice of Full Investigation dated November 21, 2002, acknowledges that Client Bâ€™s file was sent by overnight mail at a date later than May 2, 2002, and further states that respondent â€œstill plans to make every effort to refund $550 to [Client B] as soon as she is able to do so.â€Â  
As of the date of the Agreement, respondent had not refunded the $550 to Client B.Â  
Matter IV
Client C retained respondent in a domestic matter and paid her $2,190.Â  The court subsequently ordered Client Câ€™s husband to pay $1,188 of Client Câ€™s attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Respondent received and retained the $1,188 as additional fees for herself. 
Respondent represents that the attorneyâ€™s fee award by the court was for additional work on behalf of Client C for which Client C had not paid.Â  In her Response to Notice of Full Investigation, respondent stated:

The hearing proceedings went on for an extended period of time.Â  The Court was not able to break for lunch, because what was intended to be a hearing took the length of a trial.Â  In the Courtâ€™s award of attorneyâ€™s fees and other awards, the Court noted a lot of the Courtâ€™s time had been expended on the [Client C] matter.Â  Accordingly, it required unanticipated attorney time, which [respondent] believes entitled her to additional fees. In any event, [respondentâ€™s] time spent on the matter exceeded the attorneyâ€™s fees paid.Â  

Matter V
Client D hired respondent to represent him in a Department of Social Services matter.Â  Client D agreed to pay respondent $2,500. Â Client D made the last payment of $250 to respondent on December 14, 2001.Â  Respondent was suspended on January 28, 2002.Â  The matter had not been concluded at the time of respondentâ€™s suspension.Â  
Client D alleges respondent failed to inform him of her suspension and that respondent told him in May 2002 that respondent had made arrangements for another attorney to handle his case.Â  However, when Client D called the other attorney, he was told the attorney would not be able to take his case because respondent had already been paid the full fee.Â  
In her response to the Notice of Full Investigation, respondent stated:

Â [she] represented [Client D] in a matter brought against him by the Department of Social Services, performing various specific tasks for which he would make periodic payments to her.Â  [Respondent] represented him in Court, met with witnesses, and met with the Department of Social Services among other things.Â  [Respondent] was suspended from the practice of law on January 28, 2002 and it was [her] understanding that [Client D] signed an order substituting [another attorney] as his attorney in this matter.Â  [Respondent] understood that [the other attorney] would complete the representation of [Client D] and first learned of [Client Dâ€™s] allegations on receipt of the Notice of Full Investigation.

Respondent acknowledges she did not pay any portion of the fee Client D had paid to her to the attorney she arranged to handle Client Dâ€™s case.Â  
Matter VI
Respondent represented Client E on municipal court charges of failing to register a vehicle, driving under suspension, and operating an uninsured vehicle.Â  At a court appearance on March 29, 2000, respondent told Client E to wait in the hall.Â  Client E alleges that, after approximately one hour, respondent came out and told him â€œeverything was straightened outâ€ and handed Client E his driverâ€™s license. 
On July 14, 2002, Client E was stopped for another traffic violation and charged with third offense driving under suspension.Â  One of the prior DUS convictions that caused the July 2002 violation to be a third offense was the matter on which respondent represented Client E in March 2000.Â  
Respondent did not respond to ODCâ€™s requests in this matter.Â  Respondent notified ODC on December 17, 2003, that she was in the process of locating her file and that a response to the Notice of Full Investigation would be submitted as soon as possible.Â  As of the date of the Agreement, respondent has neither responded to the Notice of Full Investigation nor submitted her file to ODC.Â  Respondent represents that she has not been able to locate her file and believed that she responded to the Notice of Full Investigation by submitting to questioning under oath by ODC.Â  
Matter VII
In January 2001, Client F was injured in a car accident; Client F retained respondent.Â  After resolving the matter, respondent disbursed the proceeds.Â  Client F alleged respondent failed to pay $98 to a medical provider.Â  
Respondent believes all disbursements were made, but has not been able to locate her file to confirm this belief.Â  For purposes of this Agreement, respondent does not dispute Client Fâ€™s claim and takes the position that any failure to disburse funds was inadvertent.Â  
Matter VIII
Respondentâ€™s clients made claims to the Lawyersâ€™ Fund totaling $11,470.Â  The Lawyersâ€™ Fund awarded respondentâ€™s clients $10,420, including the $2,500 awarded to Client A.Â  Respondent has not reimbursed her clients or the Lawyersâ€™ Fund.Â  She acknowledges her statement â€œI have promptly refunded any fees paid in advance that have not been earnedâ€ in her February 12, 2002 affidavit was inaccurate.Â Â Â  
Respondent acknowledges that she had not fully cooperated with ODC in the investigation of these matters.Â  She agreed to appear at ODCâ€™s office on January 7, 2004, for an appearance under oath pursuant to Rule 19(c)(4), RLDE, and agreed to bring with her files previously subpoenaed by ODC.Â  Although respondent appeared, she did not produce the files.Â  Respondent explained that the files were in storage and she had not had time to locate them despite the fact that prior subpoenas for the files had been
issued. 
During her appearance on January 7, 2004, respondent agreed to retrieve the files and provide them to ODC.Â  The appearance was recessed to give respondent the opportunity to retrieve the files.Â  As of the date of the Agreement, respondent had not provided the files to ODC.Â  Respondent represents she has not been able to locate the files.Â Â Â Â  
LAW
Respondent admits that her misconduct constitutes grounds for discipline under Rule 413, RLDE, specifically Rule 7(a)(1) (lawyer shall not violate Rules of Professional Conduct or any other rules of this jurisdiction regarding professional conduct of lawyers) and Rule 30 (listing requirements for suspended lawyer).Â  In addition, respondent admits she has violated the following provisions of the Rules of Professional Conduct, Rule 407, SCACR:Â  Rule 1.4 (lawyer shall keep client reasonably informed about the status of a matter and promptly comply with reasonable requests for information); Â Â Â Rule 1.5 (lawyer shall charge reasonable fee); Rule 1.15 (lawyer shall promptly deliver funds which belong to third person); Rule 1.16(d) (upon termination of representation, lawyer shall take steps to the extent reasonably practicable to protect clientâ€™s interests, including giving reasonable notice to client and refunding unearned funds)Â Â Â Â Â  Rule 8.1 (lawyer shall not knowingly fail to respond to lawful demand from disciplinary authority); and Rule 8.4(a) (it shall be professional misconduct for lawyer to violate Rules of Professional Conduct).[2]  
CONCLUSION
We accept the Agreement for Discipline by Consent and impose a two year definite suspension from the practice of law.Â  We deny respondentâ€™s request to apply the suspension retroactively to the date of her previous suspension.Â  Within fifteen days of the date of this opinion, respondent shall file an affidavit with the Clerk of Court showing that she has complied with Rule 30, RLDE, Rule 413,
SCACR.
In addition, respondent shall pay restitution to all presently known and/or subsequently identified clients, banks, and other persons and entities who have incurred losses as a result of her misconduct in connection with these matters.Â  Respondent shall also reimburse the Lawyersâ€™ Fund for any claims paid as a result of her misconduct in connection with these matters.Â  ODC is directed to establish a restitution plan for respondent.[3]Â Â  
 DEFINITE SUSPENSION.
 TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ.,
concur.

[1] Respondent has not sought to be reinstated pursuant to Rule 33, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR.Â  
[2] Respondentâ€™s misconduct occurred before the effective date of the Amendments to the Rules of Professional Conduct.Â  See Court Order dated June 20, 2005.Â  The Rules cited in this opinion are those which were in effect at the time of respondentâ€™s misconduct.Â  
[3] We note respondent has specifically agreed not to apply for reinstatement unless and until all restitution has been paid in full.Â

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
In the Matter of Timothy Vincent Norton, Respondent.
      
    
  


Opinion No. 26066
Submitted September 27, 2005 - Filed November 14, 2005

INDEFINITE SUSPENSION


  
    
      
Henry B. Richardson, Jr., Disciplinary Counsel, and Susan M. Johnston, Deputy Disciplinary Counsel, both of Columbia, for Office of Disciplinary Counsel. 
Coming B. Gibbs, Jr., of Gibbs & Holmes, of Charleston, for respondent. 
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â Â  In this attorney disciplinary matter, respondent and the Office of Disciplinary Counsel (ODC) have entered into an Agreement for Discipline by Consent pursuant to Rule 21, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR.Â  In the agreement, respondent admits misconduct and consents to a definite suspension not to exceed two years or an indefinite suspension, provided the indefinite suspension is made retroactive to the date of his interim suspension.[1]Â  We accept the agreement and indefinitely suspend respondent from the practice of law in this state.Â  The facts, as set forth in the agreement, are as follows. 
FACTS
The Domestic Matters
In two family court actions, respondent did not complete qualified domestic relations orders and submit filings in a timely manner.Â  Respondent did not respond to his clientsâ€™ inquiries which caused delays and, in some instances, prejudice to the rights of his clients.Â  
The Criminal Matters
In two matters, respondent took fees for criminal representations he did not complete.Â  In a third matter, respondent did not consult with his client before accepting the solicitorâ€™s offer to resolve a pending criminal charge and did not return the clientâ€™s file upon request, thereby causing difficulties with his clientâ€™s defense.Â  
The Client Abandonment Matter
In late March 2003, respondent was admitted to a rehabilitation center for alcohol abuse for approximately three weeks.Â  Upon his release from the center, respondent spent the weekend with his family and then left town, leaving no forwarding address, no notice to his clients, and no instructions.Â  Respondent withdrew approximately $4,000 of client funds from his escrow account prior to his departure and used these funds for his own purposes.Â  Respondent made no arrangements for his clients.Â  Â Â 
Subsequently, respondent was placed on interim suspension by the Court.Â  See Footnote 1.Â  Since that time, respondent has had difficulties in recovery and has attempted suicide.Â  
On March 23, 2004, respondent effectively completed a six month recovery program.Â  He is continuing his outpatient efforts and is currently employed in the construction field.Â  
_______
Respondent has fully cooperated with ODC in connection with this matter.Â  Â Â Â Â Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
LAW
Respondent admits that by his misconduct he has violated the following provisions of the Rules of Professional Conduct, Rule 407, SCACR:Â  Rule 1.1 (lawyer shall provide competent representation); Rule 1.3 (lawyer shall act with reasonable diligence and promptness in representing clients); Rule 1.4 (lawyer shall keep clients informed); Rule 1.5 (lawyer shall not charge excessive fee); Rule 1.15
(lawyer shall promptly deliver to client any funds or other property to which client is entitled; lawyer shall keep client funds separate from his own funds); Rule 1.16 (lawyer shall withdraw from representation if his physical or mental condition materially impairs the lawyerâ€™s ability to represent the client); Rule 3.2 (lawyer shall expedite litigation consistent with interests of client); Rule 8.4(a) (lawyer shall not violate Rules of Professional Conduct); and Rule 8.4(e) (lawyer shall not engage in conduct that is prejudicial to administration of justice).[2]
Â In addition, respondent admits his misconduct constitutes a violation of Rule 7, RLDE, of Rule 413, SCACR, specifically Rule 7(a)(1) (lawyer shall not violate Rules of Professional Conduct or any other rules of this jurisdiction regarding professional conduct of lawyers) and Rule 7(a)(5) (lawyer shall not engage in conduct tending to pollute the administration of justice or to bring the courts or the legal profession into disrepute or conduct demonstrating an unfitness to practice law).
CONCLUSION
We accept the Agreement for Discipline by Consent and indefinitely suspend respondent from the practice of law.Â  The suspension shall be retroactive to the date respondent was placed on interim suspension.Â  ODC shall 1) determine the amount of restitution owed to respondentâ€™s clients and others who have been harmed as a result of respondentâ€™s misconduct and 2) institute a meaningful restitution plan.Â  Within fifteen days of the date of this opinion, respondent shall surrender his certificate of admission to practice law in this state to the Clerk of Court and shall file an affidavit with the Clerk of Court showing that he has complied with Rule 30, RLDE, Rule 413,
SCACR.
 INDEFINITE SUSPENSION.

PER CURIAM:Â Â  In this attorney disciplinary matter, respondent and the Office of Disciplinary Counsel (ODC) have entered into an Agreement for Discipline by Consent pursuant to Rule 21, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR.Â  In the agreement, respondent admits misconduct and consents to the imposition of any sanction set forth in Rule 7(b), RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR.Â  We accept the agreement and disbar respondent.Â  The facts, as set forth in the agreement, are as follows.
FACTS
Matter I
On May 18, 2004, respondent was indicted by the State Grand Jury for the offense of distribution of cocaine by conspiracy in violation of South Carolina Code Ann. Â§ 44-53-370(b)(2002).Â  On February 18, 2005, she pled guilty and was sentenced to seven years imprisonment and fined $12,500.00, suspended upon payment of $2,000.00 and three years probation with certain conditions.[1]Â  
Matter II
Respondent represented Client A, a defendant who was in arrears on child support payments.Â  Client Aâ€™s mother made a partial payment of $1,000.00 on behalf of Client A and respondent arranged for the plaintiff to execute an affidavit that she had received the payment.Â  The plaintiff executed the affidavit.Â  
Thereafter, respondent altered the affidavit by â€œwhitening outâ€ the $1,000.00 figure and entering the full amount of Client Aâ€™s arrearage.Â  At the hearing, respondent represented to the court that full payment had been made by or on behalf of Client A and offered the affidavit in support of that representation.Â  The court did not accept the affidavit and required the plaintiff to be present to testify.Â  
At a subsequent hearing, the plaintiff testified that $1,000.00 had been the amount shown on the affidavit when she signed it.Â  It was discovered during this hearing that the original amount had been â€œwhited outâ€ and that a different amount had been written in.Â  
Respondent denied having altered the affidavit in her response to ODCâ€™s Notice of Full Investigation and, again, during her Rule 19(c)(4) interview, but now acknowledges that she did alter the affidavit and her representations to the contrary were not correct.
Matter III
Respondent was scheduled to appear in magistrateâ€™s court for a trial at 2:00 p.m.Â  Respondentâ€™s secretary telephoned the magistrateâ€™s office at approximately 12:15 p.m. and said she was unsure respondent would be able to attend the trial.Â  Respondentâ€™s secretary was instructed to call back after 1:00 to speak with a certain member of the judgeâ€™s staff.Â  Respondentâ€™s secretary called as instructed and reported that respondent would not be able to attend due to a sick child.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
The magistrate was informed of respondentâ€™s secretaryâ€™s call and called the secretary.Â  The judge denied a continuance because this was the third time respondent had called requesting a continuance just prior to the hearing.Â  
After swearing the jury, the judge was notified that respondent wanted to speak with him by telephone.Â  The judge informed respondent that the continuance was denied and gave his reasons for the ruling.Â  The judge reported respondent became upset and began using profane language toward him and continued to do so despite five or six requests to refrain from such conduct.Â  The judge eventually ended the conversation by hanging up the telephone.Â  Respondent acknowledges being upset with the judgeâ€™s denial of the continuance and to using obscenities in her conversation with the judge.Â  
Matter IV
After receiving an unfavorable ruling in court, respondent raised her voice while being addressed by the judge.Â  The judge
admonished respondent to lower her voice or be held in contempt.Â  Shortly after respondent left the courtroom, a loud thumping noise was heard along the wall bordering the jury box.Â  The noise startled the entire court, including the jury.Â  
Upon hearing the commotion, the judge ordered a bailiff to bring the person causing the disturbance into the courtroom.Â  Respondent was brought in and gave the explanation that she stomped her foot in an attempt to reseat the heel on her shoe and denied intentionally disrupting the court.Â  A sheriffâ€™s deputy who was present in the hallway gave a written statement that he saw respondent kick the wall in the hallway and heard respondent call the judge a â€œgod damn asshole.â€Â  Â Â 
In response to ODC, respondent denied using the term â€œgod damnâ€ but acknowledged calling the judge an â€œassholeâ€ under her breath.Â  Respondent further explained her heel came loose so she stamped the heel of her shoe back against the wall twice.Â  
Matter V
Respondent represented Client B on a probation revocation matter.Â  On the day before the scheduled hearing, respondent requested a continuance on the grounds that she was required to be in federal court, but did not confirm whether the continuance was granted.Â  The hearing went forward and Client Bâ€™s probation was revoked.Â  
Matter VI
Respondent represented Client C on a charge of driving under the influence.Â  Client C alleges court was scheduled on four occasions, that he appeared as required, but that respondent did not appear at any time.Â  He further alleges respondent did not inform him that she was not able to appear.Â  
Respondent acknowledges that Client Câ€™s matter had been scheduled for court on a number of occasions but that she was required to be in a court of higher jurisdiction and that, in any event, the delays were ultimately in Client Câ€™s best interest.Â  Respondent further represents that she thought Client C had been notified of the conflicts but acknowledges that, in the press of business, such notification may not have been sent.Â  
Matter VII
Respondent represented Client D on various traffic charges pending in Charleston Municipal Court.Â  Respondent made inconsistent statements to the prosecutor concerning receipt of notice of certain court proceedings and requests for continuances.Â  Client Dâ€™s case was removed from the jury roster after it became apparent respondent failed to appear.Â  
Matter VIII
Respondent ordered a transcript from a court reporter.Â  She failed to pay for the transcript.Â Â  Â 
LAW

Rule 1.4 (lawyer shall keep client reasonably informed about status of a matter and promptly comply with reasonable requests for information); Rule 3.1 (lawyer shall not assert an issue unless there is a basis for doing so that is not frivolous); Rule 3.2 (lawyer shall make reasonable efforts to expedite litigation consistent with interests of client); Rule 3.3 (lawyer shall not make false statement of fact to tribunal); Rule 3.4 (lawyer shall not unlawfully alter a document having potential evidentiary value; lawyer shall not falsify evidence); Rule 3.5 (lawyer shall not engage in conduct intended to disrupt a tribunal); Rule 4.1 (in the course of representing a client, lawyer shall not knowingly make a false statement of material fact or law to a third person); Rule 8.4(a) (it is professional misconduct for lawyer to violate Rules of Professional Conduct); Rule 8.4(b) (it is professional misconduct for lawyer to commit a criminal act that reflects adversely on the lawyerâ€™s honesty, trustworthiness or fitness as a lawyer in other respects); Rule 8.4(c) (it is professional misconduct for lawyer to engage in conduct involving moral turpitude); Rule 8.4(d) (it is professional misconduct for lawyer to engage in conduct involving dishonesty, fraud, deceit, or misrepresentation); and 8.4(e) (it is professional misconduct for lawyer to engage in conduct that is prejudicial to the administration of justice).[2]Â Â  Respondent further admits that her misconduct constitutes grounds for discipline under the following provisions of Rule 7, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR:Â  Rule 7(a)(1) (it shall be a ground for discipline for a lawyer to violate the Rules of Professional Conduct); Rule 7(a)(4) (it shall be ground for discipline for a lawyer to be convicted of a serious crime or crime of moral turpitude); and Rule 7(a)(5) (it shall be a ground for discipline for a lawyer to engage in conduct tending to pollute the administration of justice or to bring the courts or the legal profession into disrepute).Â  
CONCLUSION
We accept the Agreement for Discipline by Consent and disbar respondent.Â  Respondentâ€™s request that the disbarment be made retroactive to the date she was placed on interim suspension is denied.[3]Â Â Â  
Within fifteen (15) days of the date of this opinion, respondent shall file an affidavit with the Clerk of Court showing that she has complied with Rule 30 of Rule 413, SCACR, and shall also surrender her Certificate of Admission to the Practice of Law to the Clerk of Court.Â  
 DISBARRED.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur. 

[1] As indicated during the plea proceeding, respondent â€œhiredâ€ attorney Todd Anthony Strich sometime around April 2003 to work in her law office in Charleston County.Â  (ODC asserts Strich did not actually work for respondent but that respondent shared her office space at no cost in exchange for Strich attending some hearings for respondent and rendering other legal assistance when necessary).Â  Sometime after this arrangement began, respondent began purchasing cocaine from Strich in amounts ranging from one to three and one-half grams.Â  From April 2003 to April 2004, respondent received approximately eight grams of cocaine a month from Strich and others.Â  The cocaine was used by respondent and others.Â  Although respondent never accompanied Strich or others to buy cocaine, on approximately twenty occasions she pooled her money with him and with others so that cocaine could be purchased.Â
