text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
Brackenbrook North Charleston, LP, North Bluff North Charleston, LP,
Riverwoods, LLC, Ashley Arbor, LLC, et al., Appellants,
v.
The County of Charleston, Andrew Smith in his official capacity as Charleston County Treasurer, Peggy A. Moseley in her official capacity as Charleston County Auditor, and D. Michael Huggins in his official capacity as Charleston County Assessor,
Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Â R. Markley Dennis, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 26070
Heard October 19, 2005 - Filed November 28, 2005

AFFIRMED




  
    
      
G. Trenholm Walker, Andrew K. Epting, Jr., and Francis M. Ervin, II, all of Pratt, Thomas, Epting & Walker, PA, of Charleston, for Appellants.
Bernard Eugene Ferrara, Jr. and JosephÂ  Dawson, III, both of North Charleston, and M. Dawes Cooke, Jr. and P. Gunnar Nistad, both of Barnwell Whaley Patterson & Helms, of Charleston, for Respondents.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â  The circuit court found it lacked jurisdiction to entertain Appellantsâ€™ post-remittitur request for attorneysâ€™ fees because this Courtâ€™s mandate instructed the circuit court to dismiss the appeal without prejudice.Â  The circuit court also declined to entertain Appellantsâ€™ â€œMotion to Shorten Time and Determine Compliance with Supreme Court Order.â€Â  Appellants appeal.Â  We agree with Appellants that the circuit court had jurisdiction over the attorneysâ€™ fees request, but hold that Appellants were not prejudiced by the circuit courtâ€™s ruling since they are not entitled to attorneysâ€™ fees here, and agree with the circuit court that it lacked jurisdiction to determine compliance with our Order.Â  We therefore affirm.
FACTS/PRODECURAL HISTORY
In Brackenbrook North Charleston, LP v. County of Charleston, 360 S.C. 390, 602 S.E.2d 39 (2004) (Brackenbrook I), the parties cross-appealed from a number of circuit court orders, including one denying Respondentsâ€™ motion to dismiss the matter pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 12-60-3390 (2000 and Supp. 2003).Â  We found this issue dispositive of both appeals, and â€œreverse[d] the circuit court orders and remand[ed] this matter with instructions to dismiss the suit without prejudice to [Appellantsâ€™] rights to pursue their refund requestsâ€ through administrative remedies.Â  Id. at 399, 602 S.E.2d at 44-45.Â  Following this disposition of the appeals, the Court ordered the following extraordinary relief to, as Appellants characterize them in their brief, â€œwronged non-party taxpayers:â€

We are deeply concerned that other taxpayers within the class certified by the circuit court judge in this case may have forgone their administrative remedies in reliance on the orders issued in this case.Â  For this reason, and because County concedes, as it must, that it is required to return the unlawfully collected taxes, we instruct that all taxpayers within the class who have not yet filed administrative refund actions shall have 120 days after the remittitur is sent to file such claims.Â  Notice of this right shall be given to all eligible taxpayers, in writing, by County within thirty days of the filing of this opinion.

Id. at 399-400, 602 S.E.2d at 45.
After the remittitur in Brackenbrook I was returned to the circuit court, Appellants filed a â€œPetition and Motion for Award of Attorneysâ€™ Feesâ€ and a â€œMotion to Shorten Time and Determine Compliance with Supreme Court Order.â€ Â The Compliance Motion sought to have the circuit court decide whether Respondents had properly identified and notified all eligible non-party taxpayers as required by this Court in Brackenbrook I; to determine whether Respondents had accurately calculated the amount of the refunds; to determine when those refunds would be received; and to hear any other issues which might arise from the implementation of this Courtâ€™s order requiring Respondents to give notice.
On November 16, 2004, a circuit court order was filed which implemented this Courtâ€™s mandate in Brackenbrook I by dismissing Appellantsâ€™ suit without prejudice pursuant to Â§ 12-60-3390.Â  Several days later, the circuit court issued an order denying Appellantsâ€™ request for attorneysâ€™ fees and their Compliance Motion, finding that the â€œcase is ended and the action concludedâ€ by the November 16, 2004 dismissal order.Â  Appellants appeal from this order.
ISSUES

  
    
      
        1)
         Whether the circuit court properly dismissed Appellantsâ€™ motion for attorneysâ€™ fees?
      
      
        
         
      
      
        2) 
         Whether the circuit court properly declined to entertain Appellantsâ€™ motion to determine compliance with our order?
      
    
  

ANALYSIS
A.Â  Attorneysâ€™ Fees
Appellantsâ€™ requests for attorneysâ€™ fees pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-77-300 (2005)[1] was dismissed by the circuit court, apparently because the court concluded that once the underlying civil action had been dismissed, it no longer had jurisdiction over the request.Â  Appellants contend this was error, and we agree.Â  Under the fee shifting statutes at issue here, [2] a request for attorneysâ€™ fees shall be made â€œwithin thirty days following final disposition of the case.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-77-310 (2005).Â  Where there has been an appeal, â€œfinal disposition of the caseâ€ occurs when the remittitur is filed in the circuit court.Â  McDowell v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Soc. Serv., 300 S.C. 24, 386 S.E.2d 280 (Ct. App. 1989).Â  Appellantsâ€™ attorneysâ€™ fees request was made within thirty days of the circuit courtâ€™s filing of the Brackenbrook I remittitur and was therefore timely under Â§ 15-77-310.
The circuit court erred in finding it lacked jurisdiction to consider Appellantsâ€™ statutory attorneysâ€™ fees request.Â  Jurisdiction over the case vests in the circuit court upon receipt of the remittitur from the appellate court.Â  See e.g. Martin v. Paradise Cove Marina, Inc., 348 S.C. 379, 559 S.E.2d 348 (Ct. App. 2001) (jurisdiction of the circuit court to hear matters related to case after the issuance of remittitur is well-established).Â  We find, however, that Appellants cannot show prejudice warranting reversal stemming from the circuit courtâ€™s error.Â  
Section 15-77-300 permits the prevailing party in a civil action to recover attorneysâ€™ fees from an opposing political subdivision party under certain conditions.Â  Attorneysâ€™ fees may be awarded if the court finds the agency acted without substantial justification in pressing its claim, and if there are no special circumstances that would make an attorneyâ€™s fee award unjust.Â  Id.Â  Here, the â€œclaimâ€ pressed by Respondents in Brackenbrook I was that the circuit court was not the proper forum for adjudicating Appellantsâ€™ tax refund request, the very issue upon which Respondents prevailed on appeal.Â  Appellants cannot meet the statutory requirement of demonstrating that Respondents acted without substantial justification.[3]Â  Accordingly, they are not entitled to reversal on this ground.Â  Owners Ins. Co. v. Clayton, 364 S.C. 555, 614 S.E.2d 611 (2005) (error without prejudice does not require this Court to reverse).Â  
B.Â  Motion to Shorten Time and Determine Compliance
Appellants contend that upon receipt of the remittitur, the circuit court was vested with authority to enforce this Courtâ€™s mandate in Brackenbrook I.Â  We agree.Â  E.g., Martin v. Paradise Cove, supra. The mandate is the â€œ[o]fficial mode of communicating judgment of appellate court to lower court, directing action to be taken or disposition to be made of cause by trial court.â€Â  Blackâ€™s Law Dictionary 867 (5th Ed. 1978).Â  Here, the â€˜disposition of the causeâ€™ was the dismissal of Appellantsâ€™ suit without prejudice since it had been brought in the wrong forum. Â On the other hand, our instruction to Respondents to promptly notify all affected taxpayers[4] who had not already brought an administrative action of their right to a refund was not a part of Appellantsâ€™ cause, and thus not a part of our mandate.Â  It was instead a directive to a party to take action for the benefit of non-parties.Â  
The notification requirement originated with this Court in an effort to treat non-parties fairly, and to expedite the refunds due them.Â  Respondentsâ€™ failure to comply with this directive would offend this Court, not the circuit court.Â  If a person within the class created by our directive were aggrieved by Respondentsâ€™ failure to comply with it, then her remedy would be a Rule to Show Cause filed in this Court.
The circuit court did not err in finding it lacked jurisdiction over
Appellantsâ€™ â€œMotion to Shorten Time and Determine Compliance with Supreme Court Order.â€ 
CONCLUSION
The circuit court properly declined to entertain Appellantsâ€™ Motion to Shorten Time and Determine Compliance.Â  While it erred in refusing to hear Appellantsâ€™ motion for a statutory attorneysâ€™ fee, Appellants cannot demonstrate any resulting prejudice.Â  Accordingly, the circuit court order is
 AFFIRMED.
 TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

[1] Appellants also sought to recover attorneysâ€™ fees under a â€œcommon fundâ€ theory.Â  See e.g. Petition of Crum, 196 S.C. 528, 14 S.E.2d 21 (1941) (under certain circumstances court has equitable jurisdiction to award an attorneyâ€™s fee to a party creating or preserving a common fund).Â  At oral argument, however, Appellants informed the Court they were no longer pursuing this theory as the basis for a fee award.
[2] S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 15-77-300 through -340 (2005).
[3] We do not suggest that Respondentsâ€™ conduct throughout this entire tax fiasco has been â€˜substantially justified.â€™Â  The statutory attorneysâ€™ fees relate to the civil action only, where Respondentsâ€™ defense was successful.
[4] Appellants, having already filed for an administrative refund, were not beneficiaries of the Courtâ€™s notification directive to Respondents.

title: State v. Bowman
description: This capital case involves issues regarding subject matter jurisdiction, an instruction to the jury, suppression of evidence and whether a mistrial should have been granted.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Marion Bowman, Jr., Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal from Dorchester County
Â Diane Schafer Goodstein, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 26071
Heard October 6, 2005 - Filed November 28, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Robert M. Dudek, of the South Carolina Office of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, Assistant Attorney General S. Creighton Waters, all of Columbia; and Solicitor David M. Pascoe, Jr., of Summerville, for respondent.
      
    
  

___________
 JUSTICE MOORE:Â  Appellant was charged with murder and third-degree arson.Â  The jury found appellant guilty as charged and he was sentenced to death for the murder charge and a ten-year imprisonment term for the arson charge.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
On February 17, 2001, Kandee Martinâ€™s (victimâ€™s) body was found in the trunk of her burned car.Â  She had been shot to death before being placed in the trunk.
The previous day, several people gathered at Hank Kogerâ€™s house to socialize and drink alcohol.Â  Appellant, who was wearing black pants, arrived at Kogerâ€™s house around 11:00 a.m. that day.Â  He subsequently left to purchase meat.Â  When appellant returned, he became upset because his gun had been moved.Â  He accused James Tywan Gadson (Gadson)[1] of taking the gun out of the trash barrel located on Kogerâ€™s property.Â  Hiram Johnson intervened and told appellant he had moved the gun.Â  The gun was a .380 caliber pistol that appellant had purchased a few weeks before in the presence of Gadson and Travis Felder.Â  After retrieving his gun, appellant left Kogerâ€™s house.
Later that afternoon, appellant was riding in the car of his sister, Yolanda Bowman, with another woman, Katrina West.Â  Appellant, who had a gun in his back pocket, was sitting in the back seat.Â  He instructed Yolanda to park beside the victimâ€™s car. Â At the time, the victim was speaking to a man.Â  Appellant tried to get the victimâ€™s attention, but she indicated to him that he should wait a moment.Â  The man, Yolanda, and Katrina testified as to what appellant said next.Â  The man stated that appellant said, â€œFuck waiting a minute.Â  Iâ€™m about to kill this bitch.â€Â  Yolanda stated that appellant said, â€œFuck it, that bitch.Â  That bitch be dead by dark.â€Â  Katrina stated that appellant said, â€œFuck that ride.Â  That bitch be dead by dark fall.â€Â  After appellantâ€™s comments, Yolanda drove away and appellant informed her the victim owed him money.
Around 7:30 p.m. that evening, Tywan Gadson saw appellant riding with the victim in her car.Â  They stopped and appellant told Gadson to get in. Â Gadson had been drinking alcohol since 1:00 and was â€œfeeling in good shape.â€Â  The victim stopped for gas and they drove off without paying.Â  Appellant allegedly instructed the victim where to drive and instructed her to stop on Nursery Road.Â  Gadson and appellant then exited the vehicle and walked down the road while the victim remained in the car.Â  Appellant told Gadson he was going to kill the victim because she had on a wire.Â  The victim then came down the road, grabbed appellantâ€™s arm and stated she was scared.Â  At this point, a car drove by and they all jumped into the woods.Â  Then, the victim started walking to the car with appellant following her.Â  Appellant allegedly shot his gun three times.Â  Gadson stated the victim ran toward him and then stopped and faced appellant and told him to please not shoot her anymore because she had a child to take care of.Â  Gadson stated appellant shot two more times.Â  The victim fell to the ground and appellant dragged her body into the woods.Â  Gadson stated he jumped into the car.
Afterwards, appellant and Gadson parked the victimâ€™s car and later retrieved Yolandaâ€™s car.Â  They then went to a store to purchase beer and went back to Kogerâ€™s house around 8:00 p.m.Â  Later, Gadson stayed at Kogerâ€™s house and appellant left.Â  Around 11:30 p.m., appellant and Hiram Johnson approached James Gadson, Gadsonâ€™s father.Â  Appellant gave him money to buy four pairs of gloves.
Appellant, Gadson, Hiram Johnson, and Darian Williams, then drove to Murrayâ€™s Club in the victimâ€™s car.Â  Appellant handed out the gloves for the occupants to wear and stated he had stolen the car.Â  They reached the club around midnight.Â  Once at the club, appellant tried to sell the victimâ€™s car.Â  Appellant, according to Hiram Johnson, said, â€œI killed Kandee, heh, heh, heh.â€Â  Appellant had a gun with him while at the club.Â  They left the club an hour or two after arriving there.
Three people, Carolyn Brown, Valorna Smith, and Travis Felder, left the club together.Â  They stopped by a gas station about 3:00 a.m. before proceeding to Valornaâ€™s home.Â  Not long after they were there, appellant knocked on the door and asked for Travis.Â  Travis left and came back after a few minutes.Â  He seemed normal upon his return. 
Travis testified appellant, who was wearing black jeans at the time, stated he needed Travisâ€™ help to park a car which turned out to be the victimâ€™s car.Â  Travis followed appellant to Nursery Road.Â  Appellant parked the car, went into the woods and pulled the victimâ€™s body out by her feet.Â  Appellant then put her body in the trunk.Â  While putting her body in the trunk, Travis saw a gun tucked into appellantâ€™s waist.Â  Appellant allegedly told Travis, â€œyou didnâ€™t think I did it, did you?â€Â  Travis testified appellant also stated, â€œI killed Kandee Martin.â€ Â Appellant lit the car on fire.Â  Travis then took appellant to his home and went back to Valornaâ€™s house.[2]
A resident of Nursery Road who had previously heard gunshots was awakened late in the night by a loud noise.Â  He investigated and discovered a car on fire.Â  The fire was reported at 3:54 a.m.Â  There were .380 Winchester cartridge casings found not far from the scene.Â  The casings, a blood stain, and a shoe were located with the help of a man who had driven by and seen the victimâ€™s car stopped on the road around 8:00 p.m. the previous evening.
The next day, police arrested appellant at his wifeâ€™s house and seized his black pants.Â  His wife testified he had been wearing the pants when he arrived at the house.Â  They found a wristwatch belonging to the victim in appellantâ€™s pants.
After the police left, appellantâ€™s wife, Dorothy Bowman, found appellantâ€™s gun in a chair in her home.Â  She allegedly gave the gun to appellantâ€™s father.Â  The next day, appellantâ€™s father, Yolanda, and appellantâ€™s other sister, Kendra, took the gun and dropped it off a bridge into the Edisto River.Â  It was later retrieved from the Edisto River and determined to be the gun that was used in the murder.
The arson investigator testified there was the presence of a heavy petroleum product on appellantâ€™s jeans, but the product was not gasoline.Â  The items found in the car had gasoline on them indicating that was the product used to start the fire.
While the following evidence did not come out during the guilt phase, during the sentencing phase, a video was introduced during Travis Felderâ€™s testimony.Â  The video showed Travis purchasing gasoline in a gasoline can at about 3:14 a.m.Â  Appellant was not with him on the video.Â  Travis stated appellant gave him the can for the gas and told him he needed $2-3 worth.Â  When appellant set fire to the victimâ€™s car, he retrieved the gas can from Travisâ€™ car.
At the conclusion of the guilt phase, the jury found appellant guilty of murder and third-degree arson.
ISSUES

  
    
      
        I. 
         Did the trial court err by failing to instruct the jury on the substantial impairment mitigating circumstance?
      
      
        
        
      
      
        II.
         Did the trial court err by refusing to grant a mistrial when the solicitor cross-examined a witness about the possibility of escape and did the trial court abuse its discretion by allowing the solicitor on re-cross examination of the witness to ask him about prison conditions?
      
      
        
        
      
      
        III.
         Was the trial court without subject matter jurisdiction to try appellant for capital murder?
      
      
        
        
      
      
        IV. 
         Did the trial court err by refusing to suppress the watch and liquid material found on appellantâ€™s pants because the pants were seized during an allegedly illegal
          arrest?
      
    
  

DISCUSSION
I
During the sentencing phase of appellantâ€™s trial, appellant offered mitigating evidence that there was a history of heavy alcohol use on his motherâ€™s side of the family. Â In the fourth grade, he began experimenting with alcohol by stealing sips from his uncleâ€™s drinks.Â  By age 14, appellant was selling drugs and drinking on the weekends.Â  Subsequently, he was drinking every day.
At the end of the sentencing phase, appellant requested the trial court charge the mitigating circumstance that his capacity to appreciate the criminality of his conduct or to conform his conduct to the requirements of the law was substantially impaired.[3]Â  The State objected that evidence of this mitigating circumstance was not before the jury because appellant did not want to bring up a diagnosis, if any, regarding a mental health condition that he might have.Â  The trial court ruled the record was void of the requested mitigating factor.
The trial court charged the jury on the mitigating circumstances that appellant did not have a significant history of prior criminal convictions involving the use of violence against another person, that the jury should consider appellantâ€™s age or mentality at the time of the crime, and that the jury should consider any other non-statutory mitigating factors.
Appellant argues the trial court erred by failing to charge the jury on the statutory mitigating circumstance regarding substantial impairment based on the evidence of appellantâ€™s history of substance abuse, the evidence appellant had been drinking the day of the murder, and the evidence of the â€œparty atmosphereâ€ throughout the day.
The trial court must submit for the juryâ€™s consideration any statutory mitigating circumstances supported by the evidence.Â  State v. Vazquez, 364 S.C. 293, 613 S.E.2d 359 (2005). Â The trial judge must make an initial determination of which statutory mitigating circumstances have evidentiary support and then allow the defendant to request any additional statutory mitigating circumstances supported in the record.Â  Id.Â  Absent a request by counsel to charge the mitigating circumstances, the issue is not preserved for review.Â  Id.Â  However, when there is evidence the defendant was intoxicated at the time of the crime, the trial court is required to submit the mitigating circumstances in Â§ 16-3-20(C)(b)(2), (6), and (7).Â  Id. (citing State v. Stone, 350 S.C. 442, 567 S.E.2d 244 (2002) (holding trial court is required to submit mitigating circumstances if there is evidence of intoxication regardless of whether they are requested)); see also State v. Pierce, 289 S.C. 430, 346 S.E.2d 707 (1986)[4] (evidence of voluntary intoxication is proper matter for consideration by jury in mitigation of punishment).Â  Where there is evidence the defendant was extremely intoxicated during the commission of the crime, the failure to instruct the jury on statutory mitigating circumstances (2), (6), and (7)[5] is not harmless error.Â  State v. Stone, supra.
In the present case, there was evidence presented that appellant possessed beer at different points in the day but none of the evidence indicated appellant was drinking the beer.Â  There was evidence appellant had a history of alcohol and drug abuse; however, his history is irrelevant to whether he was in fact intoxicated on the day of the murder.Â  Appellant presented no evidence he was actually intoxicated at the time of the crime.Â  The evidence indicated appellant may have been drinking that day, but this is not enough to warrant a charge to the jury for the mitigating factor outlined in Â§ 16-3-20(C)(b)(6).Â  See, e.g., State v. Vazquez, supra (holding that even though drinking was admitted, there was no evidence defendant was intoxicated at time crime was committed; therefore, court did not err by failing to charge the jury on mitigating circumstances relating to intoxication); State v. Drayton, 293 S.C. 417, 361 S.E.2d 329 (1987), cert. denied, 484 U.S. 1079 (1988) (same).Â  Cf. State v. Young, 305 S.C. 380, 409 S.E.2d 352 (1991) (where there is evidence defendant was intoxicated at time of crime, trial judge required to submit mitigating circumstances relating to intoxication).Â  Therefore, the trial courtâ€™s decision not to charge the jury on the mitigating circumstances relating to intoxication was not in error.
II
Appellant argues the trial court erred by refusing to grant a mistrial when the State asked James Aiken, a correctional consultant testifying on behalf of appellant, about the possibility of escape and by allowing the State, on re-cross examination, to ask Aiken about prison conditions.
During the sentencing phase, Aiken testified that, as a consultant, he assists in the classification of prisoners and in the training of prison wardens.Â  He testified that if appellant received a life without parole sentence, then he would stay in prison until he was dead.Â  Aiken stated appellant has adjusted relatively well to jail in the past and that he could adapt to prison life in the future.Â  Aiken mentioned appellant would be kept behind gun towers, fences, bars, and concrete.
On cross-examination, Aiken testified inmates can move to less restrictive environments within prison based on their behavior.Â  He stated appellant would never be allowed in a work-release program.Â  He further stated he did not anticipate appellant being disruptive in prison.
On redirect examination by appellantâ€™s attorney, Aiken testified appellant would not be going to a â€œkiddy campâ€ or a place where he could have â€œpicnic lunches outside the gate.â€Â  Aiken stated appellant would work because the inmates are usually required to perform cheap labor to pay back society.Â  He further testified that while appellant would stay in prison for life, he could salvage his life and have redeeming qualities.
On re-cross examination by the State, Aiken repeated his testimony that appellant would never get out of prison if he received a life without parole sentence.Â  The State then asked, â€œDuring the time that you have been affiliated with the Department of Corrections of South Carolina, how many inmates have escaped?â€Â  Appellant immediately objected.Â  A bench conference was held outside the presence of the jury.Â  The State argued appellant opened the door to the testimony by eliciting testimony from Aiken that appellant â€œwill never get out of that prison.â€
The trial court concluded the escape testimony should not be presented to the jury.Â  The trial court distinguished appellantâ€™s situation from the situation in State v. Plath, 281 S.C. 1, 313 S.E.2d 619, cert. denied, Arnold v. South Carolina, 467 U.S. 1265 (1984), because Plath himself was an escapee[6] and, therefore, escape testimony was relevant in that case.Â  Appellant made a motion for mistrial of the sentencing phase based on the escape question.Â  The court denied the motion and offered to give a curative instruction instead.Â  The court instructed the jury upon their return:

. . . there was a question that was asked before you left and I have ruled that the question was not a proper question and Iâ€™m going to ask you to disavow that from your minds for this reason:Â  There are two sentences that you will concern yourselves and weâ€™re going to have an opportunity during my charge to talk about them at great length, but for this moment I will tell you, and I think I am reminding you based on the instructions that you have received even preliminarily, but there are two sentences that you will concern yourselves.Â  One, the death penalty, and the other is life imprisonment without the possibility of parole.Â  The statute says until the death of the defendant.Â  Those would be the two sentences that you will concern yourselves.

Prior to the motion for mistrial, the State requested that, because appellant had established prison was not a â€œkiddy campâ€ and that appellant would probably not be in super maximum security, the State would like to pursue those areas by asking about certain conditions of the general population, such as the work conditions appellant had already covered.Â  The court ruled the State could do so.Â  Appellant responded, â€œWeâ€™re on recross, Judge.â€Â  The court replied that it understood, but ruled the State could go into those areas because those issues â€œare certainly before the jury at this point.â€
The re-cross examination of Aiken continued after the curative instruction was given.Â  Aiken testified appellant would not be in super maximum security and he would be able to work and earn a small amount of money.Â  Aiken testified appellant would most likely have certain opportunities in prison, such as bible study, continuing his education, participating in anger management programs, playing basketball, exercising, reading books, and watching movies and possibly television.Â  Aiken made it clear that all of these activities would occur under continuous security.
Mistrial due to Escape Question
We have held in the past that evidence of a prior escape is proper reply to a defendantâ€™s presentation of evidence of his good conduct while in prison.Â  See State v. Woomer, 278 S.C. 468, 299 S.E.2d 317 (1982), cert. denied, 463 U.S. 1229 (1983).Â  We have also held that evidence the defendant was an escapee at the time he committed a murder was admissible evidence in the sentencing phase.Â  See State v. Plath, supra.Â  Appellantâ€™s situation, however, is distinguishable from Woomer and Plath in the sense that he has never been an escapee and there was no evidence he had ever attempted to escape confinement.Â  The trial court therefore properly refused to allow Aiken to answer the Stateâ€™s question.
We find the courtâ€™s curative instruction removed any prejudice because it made it clear that the question asked by the State was improper and asked the jury to disavow that question from their minds.Â  Further, the curative instruction, without mentioning the contents of the escape question again, emphasized that the jury was to be concerned with only two sentences:Â  death and life without the possibility of parole, and that life without parole meant â€œuntil the death of the defendant.â€ Â This instruction was sufficient to cure any alleged prejudice caused by the Stateâ€™s question.Â  Therefore, we hold the trial court did not err by refusing to grant a mistrial in light of its curative instruction.Â  See State v. Vazquez, 364 S.C. 293, 613 S.E.2d 359 (2005) (mistrial should be ordered only when an incident is so grievous that prejudicial effect cannot be removed).
Prison Conditions Questions
Appellant argues the trial court erred by allowing the State, on re-cross examination, to ask Aiken about prison conditions.
We find this issue is not preserved for review because appellant did not raise this issue to the trial court before the testimony was presented and did not make a contemporaneous objection when the testimony was actually elicited.Â  Further, the trial court did not rule on this issue as now stated by appellant.Â  See State v. Moore, 357 S.C. 458, 593 S.E.2d 608 (2004) (to be preserved for appeal, issue must be raised to and ruled on by trial court); State v. Byram, 326 S.C. 107, 485 S.E.2d 360 (1997) (party cannot argue one ground below and then argue different ground on appeal).Â  See also State v. Johnson, 363 S.C. 53, 609 S.E.2d 520 (2005) (to preserve an issue for review there must be a
contemporaneous objection that is ruled upon by the trial court).
We take this opportunity, however, to caution the State and the defense that the evidence presented in a penalty phase of a capital trial is to be restricted to the individual defendant and the individual defendantâ€™s actions, behavior, and character.Â  Generally, questions regarding escape and prison conditions are not relevant to the question of whether a defendant should be sentenced to death or life imprisonment without parole.Â  We emphasize that how inmates, other than the defendant at trial, are treated in prison; and whether other inmates have escaped from prison, is inappropriate evidence in the penalty phase of a capital trial.Â  We admonish both the State and the defense that the penalty phase should focus solely on the defendant and any evidence introduced in the penalty phase should be connected to that particular defendant.
III
Appellant argues the trial court lacked subject matter jurisdiction to sentence him to death because the murder indictment did not allege an aggravating circumstance.Â  He argues that Ring v. Arizona, 536 U.S. 584 (2002), holds that aggravating factors are elements of the offense of capital murder that must be charged in the indictment.
We have recently addressed this issue in several cases.Â  See State v. Crisp, 362 S.C. 412, 608 S.E.2d 429 (2005) (under South Carolina law, aggravating circumstances need not be alleged in murder indictment); State v. Wood, 362 S.C. 135, 607 S.E.2d 57 (2004), cert. denied, Â Â Â Â Â U.S. Â Â Â Â , 125 S.Ct. 2942 (2005) (same); State v. Downs, 361 S.C. 141, 604 S.E.2d 377 (2004) (same).Â  As stated in those cases, the aggravating factors enumerated in S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-20(C)(a) (2003) are sentencing factors, not elements of murder, and they need not be in the indictment.Â  Therefore, the instant indictment is valid.
IV
Appellant argues his pants were seized during an illegal warrantless arrest and that the watch and liquid material found in and on the pants should have been suppressed.
The murder occurred in Dorchester County.Â  Appellant was arrested, on February 17, 2001, at his wifeâ€™s home in Orangeburg County pursuant to an Orangeburg County arrest warrant for receiving stolen goods that was issued on December 1, 2000.
On the morning following the murder, several officers went to the residence of appellantâ€™s wife, Dorothy.Â  The officers present were a Branchville police officer, an Orangeburg County deputy, and two officers from Dorchester County.Â  The Branchville officer testified that, although he did not have the original, he had a certified copy of the Orangeburg County warrant and that the officers went to Dorothyâ€™s house[7] pursuant to that warrant.Â  He further testified Dorothy invited him into the house and he stepped inside and told her they were looking for appellant.Â  He stated he showed Dorothy a copy of the arrest warrant.Â  Dorothy replied to him that she did not know where appellant was and indicated it was okay for the officers to look around.Â  The Branchville officer stated he did not pull out a consent to search form before searching Dorothyâ€™s home.
Dorothy confirmed the officers said they had a warrant and that she stated the officers could come in and search her home.Â  Dorothy testified she let the officers in voluntarily and they had her permission to search the home.
Appellant was found hiding behind a bed.Â  He was arrested pursuant to the receiving stolen goods warrant at that time and was transported to the Branchville Police Department.Â  At the time of his arrest, appellant was wearing only underwear and he asked for his clothes.Â  Before his wife could give him his black pants, an officer intervened to search the pants.Â  The officer wanted to check the pants for weapons for safety purposes.Â  When the officer found a ladyâ€™s watch inside the pants, the officer decided the pants needed to be confiscated.
Appellant argues the trial court should have suppressed the evidence seized at Dorothyâ€™s home because the arrest was unlawful and because Dorothy had not consented to the search.
Initially, the State argues this issue is not preserved for review because appellant did not renew his objection to the evidence when it was received at trial.
In most cases, making a motion in limine to exclude evidence at the beginning of trial does not preserve the issue for review because a motion in limine is not a final determination.Â  State v. Forrester, 343 S.C. 637, 541 S.E.2d 837 (2001); State v. Simpson, 325 S.C. 37, 479 S.E.2d 57 (1996), cert. denied, 520 U.S. 1277 (1997) (same).Â  The moving party must make a contemporaneous objection when the evidence is introduced.Â  Id.Â  An exception to this rule is where a
judge makes a ruling on the admission of evidence on the record immediately prior to the introduction of the evidence in question.Â  In that case, the aggrieved party does not need to renew the objection.Â  State v. Forrester, supra. 
Appellant did not renew his objection when the evidence of the watch found inside the pants and the petroleum on the pants was introduced.Â  The trial courtâ€™s decision to allow the evidence was not made immediately prior to the introduction of the evidence in question.Â  Therefore, this issue is not preserved for appellate review.
Despite the lack of preservation, we will address the merits.Â  When reviewing a Fourth Amendment search and seizure case, an appellate court must affirm the trial courtâ€™s ruling if there is any evidence to support the ruling.Â  State v. Missouri, 361 S.C. 107, 603 S.E.2d 594 (2004).Â  The appellate court will reverse only when there is clear error.Â  Id.
Appellant was legally arrested pursuant to a valid warrant.Â  The record indicates a warrant for receiving stolen goods had been issued prior to appellantâ€™s arrest and that the arresting officer, while possibly not in possession of the warrant itself, was acting pursuant to the warrant when the arrest was made.Â  Consequently, the trial court did not err by refusing the motion to suppress on this ground.Â  See State v. Holmes, 320 S.C. 259, 464 S.E.2d 334 (1995), cert. denied, 517 U.S. 1248 (1996) (arrest of defendant properly made and clothes seized from defendant at time of arrest could be admitted in murder prosecution, where warrant had been issued prior to arrest and arresting officer was acting pursuant to warrant, even though warrant not physically in officerâ€™s possession); State v. Sims, 304 S.C. 409, 405 S.E.2d 377 (1991), cert. denied, 502 U.S. 1103 (1992) (arresting officer who was aware but not in possession of valid arrest warrants was authorized to enter motel room to make arrest).
Further, appellant argues the motion to suppress should have been granted because his wife did not consent to the search of her home.Â  This argument is without merit because appellantâ€™s wife specifically testified she gave the officers permission to enter and search the home.Â  There is no evidence to support appellantâ€™s assertion.Â  Cf. Steagald v. United States, 451 U.S. 204 (1981) (warrantless searches of a home are impermissible absent consent or exigent circumstances).
Additionally, the search of appellantâ€™s pants and the seizure of those pants and the watch were permissible as a search incident to arrest.Â  After being arrested, appellant requested that he be allowed to put on his pants.Â  However, before being given the pants, the officer determined the pants should be searched for â€œsafety purposes.â€Â  This search was reasonable.Â  See Chimel v. California, 395 U.S. 752 (1969) (ample justification for a search of arresteeâ€™s person and area within his immediate control, that is, the area from within which he might gain possession of a weapon or destructible evidence); State v. Crowe, 258 S.C. 258, 188 S.E.2d 379, cert. denied, 409 U.S. 1077 (1972) (same).Â  See also State v. Brown, 289 S.C. 581, 347 S.E.2d 882 (1986) (search may be conducted incident to an arrest only if it is substantially contemporaneous with the arrest and is confined to the immediate vicinity of the arrest).
Accordingly, the trial court did not err by refusing to suppress the evidence as requested by appellant.Â  See State v. Missouri, supra (appellate court must affirm trial courtâ€™s ruling if there is any evidence to support the ruling).
PROPORTIONALITY REVIEW
Under State law, S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-25(C)(3) (2003) requires us to determine in a death case â€œ[w]hether the sentence of death is excessive or disproportionate to the penalty imposed in similar cases, considering both the crime and the defendant.â€Â  There is no requirement the sentence be proportional to any particular case; however, death sentences have been imposed in similar cases.Â  See State v. Binney, 362 S.C. 353, 608 S.E.2d 418, cert. denied, 2005 WL 1333888 (2005); State v. Von Dohlen, 322 S.C. 234, 471 S.E.2d 689, cert. denied, 519 U.S. 972 (1996).Â  Accordingly, appellantâ€™s sentence is not disproportionate under State law.
AFFIRMED.
TOAL, C.J., WALLER, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

[1]In connection with the victimâ€™s murder, Gadson had a plea agreement wherein he would plead to accessory after the fact of murder and misprision of a felony and receive a twenty-year sentence.
[2]Travis entered into a plea agreement whereby he would be charged with accessory after the fact to third degree arson in exchange for his testimony. 
[3]S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-20(C)(b)(6) (2003).
[4]Overruled on other grounds by State v. Torrence, 305 S.C. 45, 406 S.E.2d 315 (1991). 
[5]The section 16-3-20(C)(b)(2) mitigator states the murder was committed while the defendant was under the influence of mental or emotional disturbance.Â  The section 16-3-20(C)(b)(7) mitigator states the age or mentality of the defendant at the time of the crime.Â  The trial court in the instant case charged the latter mitigating circumstance to the jury.
[6]In fact, Plath was not an escapee, but his co-defendant John Arnold, who was also an appellant in the Plath case, was the escapee.Â  Plath, 281 S.C. at 7, 313 S.E.2d at 622-623. 
[7]Appellant and his wife both testified appellant did not live at the wifeâ€™s home and that she had been living there for only a short time before appellantâ€™s arrest.

text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
James B. Vaught, Individually, and as Attorney in Fact and/or Trustee for
J.M. Vaught, Jr., the Heirs of Thomas B. Vaught, the Heirs of Jean V. Powell, Carol V. Lewis, Harry R. Vaught, Vina V. Floyd, and
W.M. Vaught, Jr., Appellants,
v.
A.O. Hardee & Sons, Inc., Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Horry County
Â Jackson V. Gregory, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 26073
Heard October 5, 2005 - Filed November 28, 2005

REVERSED AND REMANDED


  
    
      
Robert N. Hill, of Newberry; and Richard M. Lovelace, Jr., of Conway, both for Appellants.
Stephen E. Darling and Elizabeth F. Bailey, both of Haynesworth Sinkler Boyd, P.A., of Charleston, for Respondent.
      
    
  


JUSTICE BURNETT:Â  James B. Vaught, individually and
as trustee for several relatives (Appellants), raises the issue of whether the trial court erred in excluding evidence of replacement costs as part of the measure of damages for destroyed noncommercial trees.Â  We certified this case for review from the Court of Appeals pursuant to Rule 204(b), SCACR, and conclude the trial court erred in excluding evidence of the measure of damages.Â  We reverse and remand for a new trial. Â 
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Appellants own a 754-acre tract of land in Horry County which they use primarily for hunting and family picnics.Â  A few days prior to May 28, 2002, employees of A.O. Hardee & Sons, Inc. (Respondent) burned debris for construction of Highway 31 on land adjacent to Appellantsâ€™ property.Â  On May 28, windy conditions reignited a smoldering pile of debris, and embers were blown into neighboring woods.Â  The resulting fire burned approximately 21 acres of Appellantsâ€™ tract, destroying an historic tar kiln and more than 1,200 trees, including 116 live oaks. 
On January 13, 2003, Appellants filed this lawsuit alleging
Respondent negligently ignited a fire on real estate adjacent to their property and allowed that fire to escape onto the Appellantsâ€™ property.Â  Respondentâ€™s Motion in Limine requesting the trial court exclude testimony from Travis Cork, Appellantsâ€™ forestry consultant, was denied, and the trial judge ruled the proper measure of damages was the difference between the value of the property before and after the fire.Â  The trial judge determined the destroyed trees were relevant only to the extent their destruction diminished the overall value of the land. 
Appellant James Vaught testified the destruction of the tar kiln and trees devalued the land by approximately $500,000.Â  Further, the value of the burned merchantable timber was approximately $25,000, although the property had never been used for commercial purposes.Â  Cork testified he had determined the species, number, and size of the dead trees.Â  He testified the destroyed trees had little or no value as timber.Â  He proferred testimony that Appellants could be made whole by replacement of the destroyed trees.Â  Eli Adams, a nursery owner, was qualified as an expert and proferred testimony that the cost of replacing the trees was approximately $658,000, including $66,000 to replace the destroyed live oaks.
James Ryan, a forester and Respondentâ€™s witness, testified
the merchantable value of the destroyed trees was $1,070.25.Â  Ryan further testified that if the destroyed live oaks naturally resprouted, they would grow to the size of the destroyed trees in 25 to 40 years. 
The trial judge charged that shade trees and certain other type trees had value only by reason of their connection to the land, and that the fair measure of damages to such property â€œis the injury to the premises as a whole, which would be fixed by ascertaining the difference between the value of the entire premises before and after the fire . . . . [T]he difference in value rule of land before and after the fire applies to undeveloped growing timber, shade and ornamental trees.â€ 
The jury returned a verdict for Appellants in the amount of Â $20,000.Â  Appellants moved for a new trial absolute or for a new trial nisi additur, which were both denied.Â  This appeal followed.Â  
ISSUE

Did the trial court err by prohibiting Appellants from introducing evidence of replacement costs of destroyed noncommercial trees on property used for recreational purposes?Â  

STANDARD OF REVIEW
In an action at law, on appeal of a case tried by a jury, the
jurisdiction of this Court extends merely to the correction of errors of law, and a factual finding of the jury will not be disturbed unless a review of the record discloses there is no evidence which reasonably supports the juryâ€™s findings.Â  Townes Assocs., Ltd. v. City of Greenville, 266 S.C. 81, 221 S.E.2d 773 (1976).Â  The admission of evidence is within the sound discretion of the trial judge, and absent a clear abuse of discretion amounting to an error of law, the trial courtâ€™s ruling will not be disturbed on appeal. Hofer v. St. Clair, 298 S.C. 503, 513, 381 S.E.2d 736, 742 (1989).Â  An abuse of discretion occurs when the ruling is based on an error of law or a factual conclusion without evidentiary support.Â  Conner v. City of Forest Acres, 363 S.C. 460, 467, 611 S.E.2d 905, 908 (2005); Carlyle v. Tuomey Hosp., 305 S.C. 187, 193, 407 S.E.2d 630, 633 (1991).Â  To warrant reversal based on the admission or exclusion of evidence, the appellant must prove both the error of the ruling and the resulting prejudice, i.e., there is a reasonable probability the juryâ€™s verdict was influenced by the wrongly admitted or excluded evidence.Â  Conner, 363 S.C. at 467, 611 S.E.2d at 908; Hanahan v. Simpson, 326 S.C. 140, 156, 485 S.E.2d 903, 911 (1997). 
LAW/ANALYSIS
Appellants argue the trial court erred in ruling the
proper measure of damages for destroyed noncommercial trees on property used for recreational purposes was the value of the property before and after the fire and the trial court erred in excluding evidence of replacement costs of the destroyed trees.Â  We agree. 
Actual damages are properly called compensatory damages, meaning to compensate, to make the injured party whole, to put him in the same position he was in prior to the damages received insofar as this is monetarily possible. See Clark v. Cantrell, 339 S.C. 369, 529 S.E.2d 528 (2000).Â  The goal is to restore the injured party, as nearly as possible through the payment of money, to the same position he was in before the wrongful injury occurred. Id. at 378, 529 S.E.2d at 533. 
In Hall v. Seaboard Airline Railway Co., 126 S.C. 330,
332-33, 119 S.E. 910, 910-11 (1923), the Court identified two classes of property damaged by fire: 

(1) That which is essentially connected with the premises and has value only by reason of that connection, such as fruit trees, ornamental and shade trees and shrubs, the young growth of a forest, hedge, grass, and the like; (2) that which has a value independent and separate from the premises as such, such as buildings, fences, merchantable timber, corded or cut wood, and the like, the loss or damage to which is capable of practically exact estimation.Â  

At issue in the present case is property described in the first category.Â  Two general rules of damages have been applied to this type of property: diminution in value and restoration costs.Â  See 22 Am.Jur.2d Damages Â§ 276 (2003) (noting courts generally use the diminution in value rule for damage to shade or ornamental trees but under certain facts and circumstances replacement costs may be the proper measure of damages). [1]Â  To fully compensate the injured party, a court may allow the jury to consider more than one measure of damages, but damages may be awarded under only one theory. Id.Â  
The Restatement (Second) Torts Â§ 929 (1979) supports restoration costs as the proper measure of damages for injury to real property in certain circumstances.Â  Section 929 provides in part,  

(1) If one is entitled to a judgment for harm to land resulting from a past invasion and not amounting to a total destruction of value, the damages include compensation for (a) the difference between the value of the land before the harm and the value after the harm, or at his election in an appropriate case, the cost of restoration that has been or may be reasonably incurred . . . . 

Comment (b) to Â§ 929 further states, 

Even in the absence of value arising from personal use,
the reasonable cost of replacing the land in its original position is ordinarily allowable as the measure of recovery . . . . If, however, the cost of replacing the land in its original condition is disproportionate to the diminution in the value of the land caused by the trespass, unless there is a reason personal to the owner for restoring the original condition, damages are measured only by the difference between the value of the land before and after the harm.

Several courts cite with approval Â§ 929 of the Restatement.Â  See, e.g., Osborne v. Hurst, 947 P.2d 1356 (Alaska 1997); Dixon v. City of Phoenix, 845 P.2d 1107 (Ariz. Ct. App. 1993); Worthington v. Roberts, 803 S.W.2d 906 (Ark. 1991); Heninger v. Dunn, 162 Cal.Rptr. 104 (Cal. Ct. App. 1980); Klingshirn v. McNeal, 520 S.E.2d 761 (Ga. App. 1999);Leavitt v. Continental Tel. Co. of Maine, 559 A.2d 786 (Me. 1989); Rector, Wardens and Vestry of St. Christopherâ€™s Episcopal Church v. C.S. McCrossan, Inc., 235 N.W.2d 609 (Minn. 1975); Keitges v. VanDermeulen, 483 N.W.2d 137 (Neb. 1992); Denoyer v. Lamb, 490 N.E.2d 615 (Ohio Ct. App. 1984);Gross v. Jackson Township, 476 A.2d 974 (Pa. Super. Ct. 1984); Threlfall v. Town of Muscoda, 527 N.W.2d 367 (Wis. Ct .App. 1994).Â  See also Kristine Cordier Karnezis, Annotation, Measure of Damages for Injury to or Destruction of Shade or Ornamental Tree or Shrub, 95 A.L.R.3d 508 Â§ 4 (1979 & Supp. 2005) (discussing cases that allow replacement costs under certain circumstances).
In Keitges, the Nebraska Supreme Court was presented
 with the novel question of â€œwhether a plaintiff is entitled to recover the cost of restoring trees and vegetation on land which he holds for residential or recreational purposes when a portion of a natural woods is destroyed.â€ 483 N.W.2d at 140.Â  The Nebraska court concluded
Restatement (Second) Torts Â§ 929 was consistent with a prior decision which stated that â€œthe principle underlying allowance of damages is to place the injured party in the same position, so far as money can do it, as he would have been had there been no injury or breach of duty, that is, to compensate him for the injury actually sustained.â€ Id. at 142 (quoting â€œLâ€ Investments, Ltd. v. Lynch, 322 N.W.2d 651, 656 (1982)).Â  The Nebraska court further asserted:

One personâ€™s unsightly jungle may be another personâ€™s enchanted forest; certainly the owner of such land should be allowed to enjoy it free from a trespasserâ€™s bulldozer. Indeed, a trespasser should not be allowed, with impunity, to negligently or willfully wreak havoc on a landownerâ€™s natural woods, and the landownerâ€™s attempted recovery for such injury should not be entirely frustrated by the fact that the market does not reflect his personal loss.

Id. at 143.Â  The court held that a landowner who intends to use land for recreational or residential purposes, may recover restoration costs, which may not exceed the market value of the property before the injury, when trees and other growth are destroyed.
In Osborne, the plaintiffs sought to recover for damaged
trees destroyed by a fire set by defendant.Â  The trial court granted summary judgment on the issue of the measure of damages for defendant and held that restoration costs were not the proper measure of damages.Â  The Supreme Court of Alaska reversed the ruling and remanded the case to determine damages in accordance with Restatement (Second) Torts Â§ 929.Â  The court had previously recognized that â€œâ€˜a plaintiff who has been injured by an invasion of his land not totally destroying its value may elect as damages either the loss in valueâ€™ or reasonable restoration costs.â€ 947 P.2d at 1358 (citing G & A Contractors, Inc. v. Alaska Greenhouses, Inc., 517 P.2d 1379, 1385 (Alaska 1974)). The court also noted its prior holding that Â§ 929 should be used to determine whether restoration costs are appropriate. Id. at 1359.Â  Further, the court held that if the jury found the plaintiffs had a personal reason for restoring the property, then plaintiffs could elect restoration costs as the proper measure of damages.
In Rector, the plaintiff sought damages for defendantâ€™s
negligent suffocation of roots of shade trees on plaintiffâ€™s property.Â  That court noted: 

Since [1912], courts throughout the country have placed a greater emphasis on the rights of a property owner to enjoy the aesthetic value of trees and shrubbery, notwithstanding the fact they may have little commercial value or that their destruction may, indeed, even enhance the market value of the property. 

235 N.W.2d at 610.Â  The Minnesota Supreme Court departed from the traditional measure of damages which was diminution in value of the land and held â€œwhere trees and shrubbery have aesthetic value to the owner as ornamental and shade trees or for purposes of screening sound and providing privacy, replacement cost may be considered to the extent that the cost is reasonable and practical.â€ Id. at 611.Â  The court held the jury could consider restoration costs and the value of the land before and after the damage.Â  But see Baillon v. Carl Bolander & Sons Co., 235 N.W.2d 613, 615 (Minn. S.Ct. 1975) (refusing to apply the replacement cost rule when destroyed trees were â€œfor the most part, quite small, ill-formed, and not particularly desirable as shade trees or ornamental trees but did serve to prevent erosion and act as a sound barrierâ€).
The reasoning expressed in the Restatement (Second) Torts Â§ 929, Keitges, Osborne, and Rector is persuasive on the measure of damages for damaged/destroyed noncommercial trees, shrubs, and related vegetation.Â  We adopt the following as the measure of damages:Â  The general measure of damages for damaged/destroyed noncommercial trees, shrubs, and related vegetation is the difference in the value of the entire parcel of land - damaged and undamaged portions - immediately before and after the loss. Â When the property is restorable to its former condition at a cost less than the diminution in value, then the cost of restoration that has been or may be reasonably incurred or the diminution in value may be the proper measure of damages. When the cost of restoration exceeds the diminution in value, then the greater cost of restoration will be allowed when the landowner has a personal reason relating to the land for restoring the land to its original condition and when the cost of restoration is reasonable in relation to the damage inflicted.Â  However, the landowner may not recover restoration costs which exceed the market value of the entire parcel prior to the loss.Â  See 22 Am.Jur.2d Damages Â§ 256. Â Â Further, the jury may consider factors in determining the diminution in value, including but not limited to: the types and sizes of the damaged or destroyed trees and shrubs, the purpose for which the destroyed or damaged trees and shrubs were grown or maintained, the reasonable and practicable replacement costs, and the use of the particular land, including any aesthetic value to the landowners of such trees and shrubs.Â  SeeÂ  Harper v. Morris, 365 S.E.2d 176, 177-78 (N.C. Ct. App. 1988); 75 Am.Jur.2d Damages Â§ 136. 
The trial judge abused his discretion by excluding evidence
of replacement costs of the destroyed noncommercial trees.Â  There is a reasonable probability the juryâ€™s verdict was influenced by the excluded evidence because the jury was not permitted to hear and consider all relevant evidence relating to damages. See Conner, 363 S.C. at 467, 611 S.E.2d at 908. 
CONCLUSION
We conclude the trial court erred in excluding evidence of
replacement costs of the destroyed noncommercial trees and there is a reasonable probability the excluded evidence influenced the juryâ€™s verdict.Â  We decline to address Respondentâ€™s additional sustaining ground. See Iâ€™On, L.L.C. v. Town of Mt. Pleasant, 338 S.C. 406, 526 S.E.2d 716 (2000) (the Court in its discretion may address an additional sustaining ground).Â  We reverse and remand for a new trial in accordance with this opinion.Â  
 TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

[1]Â  See Thatcher v. Lane Construction Co., 254 N.E.2d 703, 707 (Ohio Ct. App. 1970) (â€œThe general rule that the measure of damages for injury to real estate shall not exceed the difference in the market value of the entire tract immediately before and immediately after the injury is not an arbitrary or exact formula to be applied in every case without regard to whether its application would compensate the injured party fully for losses which are the proximate result of the wrongdoerâ€™s conduct.â€).Â
